senses.sense: the beginning of something
senses.dict_examp: the seeds of hope/change
senses.lear_examp: Charity workers are keen to contribute with their work, their hearts and the seeds of hope and peace they leave wherever they go.

senses.sense: not often
senses.dict_examp: I seldom drive my car into the city.
senses.lear_examp: Alice was a quiet girl, she seldom talked, but he just couldn't stop talking.

senses.sense: being self-confident
senses.dict_examp: Since she left home, her self-confidence has grown.
senses.lear_examp: In my opinion, the reason for it is that not many people know how to prepare for an interview and gain self-confidence.

senses.sense: your characteristics, including your personality, your abilities, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Now I’m feeling better, and I’m back to my old self again.
senses.lear_examp: True recognition and happiness can't be derived from television or front covers but only from one's true self.

senses.sense: the quality of being confident about yourself
senses.dict_examp: He spoke with remarkable self-assurance for such a young man.
senses.lear_examp: She would have to show self-assurance, determination to get the job, and give the feeling that she would be up to the task.

senses.sense: the quality of being selfish
senses.dict_examp: I was appalled by his selfishness.
senses.lear_examp: It seems to me that everywhere in the world, people are not necessarily aware of the fact that planet Earth is the  most precious gift we have. Greed and selfishness are also very common in Switzerland, even if this country might be already a few steps further forward than others.

senses.sense: feeling sure about yourself and your abilities
senses.dict_examp: He's a very self-confident young man.
senses.lear_examp: So when the day came, she felt much more self-confident and determined than before.

senses.sense: someone who sells something
senses.dict_examp: flower/newspaper/souvenir sellers
senses.lear_examp: It was then my mother remembered a toy seller had been selling toys in the place where we had been waiting in the station and that our suitcases must have got mixed up.

senses.sense: done in a way that is intended to shock people
senses.dict_examp: sensational journalism
senses.lear_examp: I think that the journalists desired sensational news far too much and they exaggerated.

senses.sense: very exciting or extremely good
senses.dict_examp: a sensational performance
senses.lear_examp: If you are up for some sensational fun, "New York-New York" is your place, with a crazy roller coaster soaring through the lobby and out into open air.

senses.sense: a physical feeling, or the ability to physically feel things
senses.dict_examp: a burning sensation
senses.lear_examp: When I fell into the water, I was shocked. I couldn't move my right leg, the sensation was horrible.

senses.sense: a strange feeling or idea that you cannot explain
senses.dict_examp: I had the odd sensation (that) someone was following me.
senses.lear_examp: Suddenly I had the sensation that something was wrong.

senses.sense: a lot of excitement, surprise or interest
senses.dict_examp: Their marriage caused a sensation.
senses.lear_examp: In the poetry, she expressed her sad feeling, thinking of her brother who was in China as a soldier. It caused a sensation.

senses.sense: having a more important job or position than someone else
senses.dict_examp: a senior executive
senses.lear_examp: She is also extraordinary in that she graduated from Harvard University and Tokyo University and used to work for the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs as a senior civil servant.

senses.sense: relating to the fourth and final year of study in a high school, college, or university
senses.dict_examp: Alanna’s in her senior year of high school.
senses.lear_examp: They made a film about this guy in the senior class who is able to dance like a pro despite being handicapped from the waist down.

senses.sense: relating to people who are older
senses.dict_examp: You can't use a senior ticket during rush hour - you have to pay full fare.
senses.lear_examp: When I got to the tickets desk before the show to buy my ticket I asked for a senior discount, and the woman told me there were no discounts available as I read on the advertising.

senses.sense: a student in the fourth and final year of study in a high school, college, or university
senses.dict_examp: The seniors are taking their exams today.
senses.lear_examp: One day my geography teacher gathered the seniors and the juniors in our class, plus the principal and other two or three teachers, so that they could listen to me making a speech on my beautiful home-country.

senses.sense: someone over the age of 65
senses.dict_examp: Seniors get a discount.
senses.lear_examp: But we have a lot of volunteers, people who love their city, first of all students and senior citizens.

senses.sense: a group of words, usually containing a verb, that expresses a complete idea
senses.dict_examp: He's very impatient and always interrupts me mid-sentence.
senses.lear_examp: Every lesson, I read and write loads of sentences.

senses.sense: a punishment that a judge gives to someone who has committed a crime
senses.dict_examp: They each served a three-year prison sentence.
senses.lear_examp: This is even worse than a real life sentence.

senses.sense: to give a punishment to someone who has committed a crime
senses.dict_examp: He was sentenced to 3 months in jail and fined $5000.
senses.lear_examp: Soon afterwards he gets imprisoned again and is sentenced to death. Sydney takes his place and is executed instead of him.

senses.sense: a feeling or understanding about yourself or about a situation
senses.dict_examp: Did you get any sense of what they might do?
senses.lear_examp: I like to see how people fight for the prize. I like this sense of competition that only sports give!

senses.sense: the ability to understand funny things and to be funny yourself
senses.dict_examp: Carol has a wicked sense of humor.
senses.lear_examp: She is a very nice person with a very good sense of humor and moral values.

senses.sense: good judgment, especially about practical things
senses.dict_examp: I hope they'll have the (good) sense/have enough sense to shut the windows before they leave.
senses.lear_examp: People should have the sense to dispose of all the waste properly.

senses.sense: the ability to do something
senses.dict_examp: He's got a good sense of direction and hardly ever uses a map.
senses.lear_examp: Animals are part of nature so they must be free to go where their sense of direction leads them.

senses.sense: one of the five natural abilities of sight, hearing, touch, smell, and taste
senses.dict_examp: My cold is so bad I've lost my sense of smell/taste.
senses.lear_examp: You can enjoy a flight with all your five senses.

senses.sense: to have a meaning or reason that you can understand
senses.dict_examp: He's written me this note but it doesn't make any sense.
senses.lear_examp: Eighty kilometres in the mountains just to look at views doesn't make any sense to me.

senses.sense: to be a good thing to do
senses.dict_examp: It makes sense to buy now while prices are low.
senses.lear_examp: Therefore it makes sense to use the innovations.

senses.sense: one of the possible meanings of a word or phrase
senses.dict_examp: They are not immigrants, at least not in any sense that I understand.
senses.lear_examp: The Empress was an ideal lady in every sense of the word.

senses.sense: thinking about something in a particular way
senses.dict_examp: In a sense, he's right.
senses.lear_examp: In a sense this is correct, since you have to leave your natural environment to visit a place where no human being is meant to survive.

senses.sense: to understand something that is difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: I'm trying to make sense of this document.
senses.lear_examp: In fact, it's during his journey that Stevens begins to make sense of his life, of all the years he spent as a butler, as the "perfect butler" who had to be loyal, silent and discreet.

senses.sense: to realize you are wrong or have been behaving stupidly
senses.dict_examp: We talked to her for an hour, but we couldn't make her see sense.
senses.lear_examp: Ralph tries to make Jack see sense by showing him the conch which had been the symbol of leadership and also, friendship.

senses.sense: to feel or experience something without being able to explain exactly how
senses.dict_examp: Although she said nothing, I could sense her anger.
senses.lear_examp: By that time the widow could not walk and the widower could not see. When the widower sensed that the widow badly wanted to go, the widow clung onto the widower's back and they set off, with her telling him where to go.

senses.sense: one of the two games in a sports competition that are played to decide who will play in the final game
senses.dict_examp: Who's in the semi-finals?
senses.lear_examp: One Sunday morning we had to play the cup semi-final against our great rival.

senses.sense: to give something to someone else in return for money
senses.dict_examp: I sold him my car/I sold my car to him for $2000.
senses.lear_examp: I want to sell my computer.

senses.sense: to offer something for people to buy
senses.dict_examp: Excuse me, do you sell newspapers?
senses.lear_examp: We have some malls which sell clothes and I love shopping there.

senses.sense: to be available for sale at a particular price
senses.dict_examp: The shirts are selling for $30 each.
senses.lear_examp: I heard larger t-shirts are selling for €35.

senses.sense: to be bought in large numbers
senses.dict_examp: His last book sold eight million copies.
senses.lear_examp: The single with her new song sold more than 15 million copies, now she was a powerfull star.

senses.sense: to persuade someone that an idea or plan is good
senses.dict_examp: I've been trying to sell the idea to my boss.

senses.sense: to be bought quickly and in large numbers
senses.dict_examp: Their new game is selling like hotcakes.
senses.lear_examp: They will buy the products, which I'm sure will sell like hotcakes!

senses.sense: If a supply of something sells out, or if it is sold out, there is no more of that thing to buy.
senses.dict_examp: The first issue of the magazine sold out within two days.
senses.lear_examp: All the tickets were sold out and the stadium was nearly full.

senses.sense: a mark (;) used to separate parts of a sentence, or items in a list which already has commas
senses.dict_examp: Use a semicolon to separate the groups of items in your list.

senses.sense: showing good judgment
senses.dict_examp: a sensible approach/strategy/solution
senses.lear_examp: I know it sounds strange but there's a sensible reason: money talks.

senses.sense: in a sensible way
senses.dict_examp: She behaved very sensibly about it.
senses.lear_examp: As time goes by, these kids quite don't understand the importance of using money sensibly and saving money.

senses.sense: a meeting of a group of people with a teacher or expert for training, discussion, or study of a subject
senses.dict_examp: I attended practically every lecture and seminar when I was a student.
senses.lear_examp: I also need this job because I need money to attend some seminars.

senses.sense: easily upset by the things people say or do
senses.dict_examp: Her reply showed that she was very sensitive to criticism.
senses.lear_examp: Nowadays we are not so sensitive.

senses.sense: able to react very quickly and easily
senses.dict_examp: a sensitive measuring instrument
senses.lear_examp: I am very sensitive to noise, especially at night, and tend to catch a cold even in summer.

senses.sense: easy to damage and needing to be protected
senses.dict_examp: This part of Cape Hatteras is an environmentally sensitive area where sea turtles nest.

senses.sense: A sensitive subject or situation needs to be handled carefully in order to avoid upsetting people.
senses.dict_examp: Job loss and rising  costs are sensitive issues.
senses.lear_examp: I knew that I could not cry and shout because it was too important and sensitive a problem for us.

senses.sense: able to understand what people are feeling and deal with them in a way that does not upset them
senses.dict_examp: I want a man who's kind and sensitive.
senses.lear_examp: One thing Bobby is good at is that he is bright and sensitive enough to protect you.

senses.sense: the ability to understand how other people are feeling and to be helpful and kind to them
senses.dict_examp: The police showed great sensitivity in their handling of the case.
senses.lear_examp: It is written with sensitivity, honesty, sincerity and objectiveness.

senses.sense: the quality of being easily upset by things that people say or do
senses.dict_examp: I should have warned you about her sensitivity to criticism.
senses.lear_examp: One of her weaknesses would be her great sensitivity.

senses.sense: happening or done without a good reason
senses.dict_examp: senseless violence
senses.lear_examp: Maybe after a thousand years of wars between Poland and Germany both sides have finally decided that fighting and killing is senseless.

senses.sense: to arrange for something to go to or be delivered somewhere or to someone
senses.dict_examp: Juan has just sent me a text message.
senses.lear_examp: I can use the internet to learn English, and sometimes I send e-mail.

senses.sense: to make someone go somewhere
senses.dict_examp: We're sending the children to stay with my parents for a couple of weeks.
senses.lear_examp: We should build more schools because we only have one, so we have to send our children away and none of us like that.

senses.sense: to cause someone or something to do a particular thing, or to cause something to happen
senses.dict_examp: The explosion sent the crowd into a panic.
senses.lear_examp: While we were singing a duet by Mendelssohn with my sister, a sweeping movement of my hand sent two pages of music flying toward the first row of seats.

senses.sense: to make you feel afraid or excited
senses.dict_examp: The sound of his voice sent shivers down my spine.
senses.lear_examp: Simply looking at her sent shivers down his spine - there was the love of his life, the dearest woman on good old Earth, that he's never met before.

senses.sense: to return something to the person who sent it to you, especially because it is damaged or not suitable
senses.dict_examp: I had to send the shirt back because it didn't fit me.
senses.lear_examp: I usually order my clothes on the Internet.  It's fast, easy and you don't have any problems sending them back if they don't fit.

senses.sense: to send someone a message asking them to come to see you
senses.dict_examp: We had to send for a doctor.
senses.lear_examp: Immediately after his arrival he sent for Beadle.

senses.sense: to send a letter, document or parcel by mail
senses.dict_examp: Have you sent off your application yet?

senses.sense: to produce something in a way that causes it to spread out from a central point
senses.dict_examp: The laser sends out a red beam of light.
senses.lear_examp: On the other side of the lake the placid grazing cows would munch their breakfast as the sun rose on the horizon, sending out a flood of colors across the sky.

senses.sense: someone's feelings, or the ability to understand what other people feel
senses.dict_examp: his aesthetic sensibility
senses.lear_examp: All the features mentioned above are extremely important but they mean nothing if your offspring lacks kindness, sensibility and ignores his family traditions.

senses.sense: one of two periods of time that the school or university year is divided into
senses.dict_examp: fall/spring semester
senses.lear_examp: My grandmother is from Germany. That's why everybody in my family should know German. I want to start next semester.

senses.sense: to put plates, knives, forks, etc. on the table to prepare for a meal
senses.dict_examp: Could you set the table for me, please?
senses.lear_examp: We set the table and waited for Jun. He was supposed to come around six.

senses.sense: If a story, movie, etc. is set in a particular time or place, the action in it happens in that time or place.
senses.dict_examp: "West Side Story" is set in New York in the late 1950s.
senses.lear_examp: It was an adventure story and I liked it a lot because it was set in Australia.

senses.sense: to fix a date or time for something
senses.dict_examp: Juan and Maria have set a date for their wedding - it's  August 31.
senses.lear_examp: I'm going to miss your class tomorrow, but we can set a date to cover the work on.

senses.sense: When the sun sets, it moves down in the sky until it cannot be seen.
senses.dict_examp: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
senses.lear_examp: I loved the thin fog before the sun set.

senses.sense: to make a piece of equipment ready to be used
senses.dict_examp: The dishwasher is set to go on in two hours.
senses.lear_examp: I had forgotten to set the alarm clock the previous night and by the time I got up it was already 9 o'clock.

senses.sense: if something is set somewhere, it is in that place or position
senses.dict_examp: It's a new, glass building set right in the middle of my old neighborhood.
senses.lear_examp: The camp is set in a beautiful place in the heart of nature, with lots of opportunities to get out of the camp if you want to.

senses.sense: to cause something or someone to be in the stated condition or situation
senses.dict_examp: Officials believed the building was set on fire deliberately.
senses.lear_examp: A modern zoo must be like a forest, without cages, and the animals must be set free.

senses.sense: to give someone something to do or achieve
senses.dict_examp: We were set a difficult task.
senses.lear_examp: I suggest it would be a good idea to set more projections next year.

senses.sense: to do something in a good way so that other people might try to copy you
senses.dict_examp: Try to set a good example to the children.
senses.lear_examp: It sets a good example for other museums.

senses.sense: to establish the best achievement so far in a sport or competition
senses.dict_examp: Bolt has set a new world record.

senses.sense: to decide the level of something
senses.dict_examp: The interest rate has been set at 5%.
senses.lear_examp: In addition to all this, I must point out that our agreement regarding the student discount on all tickets was set at 10%, not 5%, as you mentioned on your handout.

senses.sense: to go into a place or onto a piece of land
senses.dict_examp: He told me never to set foot in his house again.
senses.lear_examp: I dream of being the first one to set foot on a white sandy beach, to admire a new kind of vegetation: cranberry bushes, sweet potatoes, wild turkeys, a different climate; how scary and exciting at the same time!

senses.sense: to establish guidelines, standards, etc. that must be followed
senses.dict_examp: Our school sets very high standards and most students achieve them.
senses.lear_examp: But I do know that even though my parents were indulgent, affectionate and warm, they still quite clearly set standards on how I was supposed to behave.

senses.sense: to put something somewhere
senses.dict_examp: She set the vase down on the table.

senses.sense: to make something start burning, usually to cause damage
senses.dict_examp: Enemy troops set fire to the village.
senses.lear_examp: At this point nothing made sense anymore, so I just watched while Jake set the car on fire.

senses.sense: to start a trip on a boat or ship
senses.dict_examp: We set sail for home the next day.
senses.lear_examp: What made things turn from gray to black was that soon after my return I was invited to set sail to the Spanish islands.

senses.sense: to decide to achieve something
senses.dict_examp: She's set her sights on becoming a doctor.
senses.lear_examp: This resemblance was the final silent argument that convinced Wormold to promise Milly the expensive and beautiful horse she had set her sights on.

senses.sense: to save something, usually money, for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: She sets aside $100 every month to save for vacation.
senses.lear_examp: You never know when you'll need extra money, so it'll be important for you to set some aside.

senses.sense: to make something happen more slowly or later than it should
senses.dict_examp: These delays have set back the publication date by a month.
senses.lear_examp: She would put off school which set her back a couple of years but she was free to choose and do what she really enjoyed doing.

senses.sense: to start a journey
senses.dict_examp: What time do we have to set off for the airport tomorrow?
senses.lear_examp: We set off for home at 5 o'clock.

senses.sense: to cause something to begin or happen, especially a loud noise or a lot of activity
senses.dict_examp: The spark set off a loud explosion.
senses.lear_examp: He would set off the smoke alarm by lighting some of his matches.

senses.sense: to begin a trip
senses.dict_examp: Martin set out on his bike ride before dawn.
senses.lear_examp: Next morning I packed my luggage and set out on our trip to France.

senses.sense: to start an activity with a particular aim
senses.dict_examp: She set out with the aim of becoming the youngest ever winner of the championship.
senses.lear_examp: That is why the day her son was named emperor a smile of satisfaction played round her lips, because at last she had achieved what she had set out to do, which was make her son ascend the throne.

senses.sense: to give all the details of something, or to explain something clearly, especially in writing
senses.dict_examp: All the project costs are set out in this proposal.
senses.lear_examp: I'm writing this composition to set out the main statements in favor of the idea that more help is needed to protect the environment.

senses.sense: to formally establish a new company, organization, system, way of working, etc.
senses.dict_examp: A committee has been set up to organize the club's social events.
senses.lear_examp: It is such a beautiful country that I wanted to stay there and set up a business.

senses.sense: to arrange for an event or activity to happen
senses.dict_examp: We need to set up a meeting to discuss the proposals.
senses.lear_examp: I suggest we try to set up a meeting with people from city hall, and give them all the right arguments.

senses.sense: a group of things that belong together
senses.dict_examp: a boxed set of DVDs
senses.lear_examp: We have to bring a notebook and a painting set.

senses.sense: a part of a game of tennis
senses.dict_examp: They won in straight sets.
senses.lear_examp: Finally we managed to win the second set so we were equal.

senses.sense: the place where a movie or play is performed or recorded, and the furniture, pictures, etc. that are used
senses.dict_examp: a movie set
senses.lear_examp: Her father, John, was a stuntperson and he died in an unfortunate accident while he was performing on a film set.

senses.sense: to be ready
senses.dict_examp: We were all set to go when the phone rang.
senses.lear_examp: So, there you go. I'm all set!

senses.sense: fixed and never changing
senses.dict_examp: Most people work a set number of hours each week.
senses.lear_examp: Even if there is a set number of standard models, there is always ample room for personal choice according to your taste.

senses.sense: a group of television or radio programs that have the same main characters or deal with the same subject
senses.dict_examp: a comedy series
senses.lear_examp: I like television series like Smallville.

senses.sense: several things or events of the same type that come one after the other
senses.dict_examp: He had a series of tests, but they can't find anything wrong.
senses.lear_examp: The aim of this report is to make a series of suggestions on which lessons and other activities should be filmed.

senses.sense: a set of books published by the same company which deal with the same subject
senses.dict_examp: They do a series on architecture throughout the ages.
senses.lear_examp: We read all of Poirot and the Miss Marple series.

senses.sense: not connected to or touching anything else
senses.dict_examp: a separate compartment
senses.lear_examp: But there was no choice, as all my friends who did go were already in separate rooms.

senses.sense: different or new
senses.dict_examp: Use a separate sheet of paper.
senses.lear_examp: Yesterday I bought a lot of presents, so I needed a separate suitcase.

senses.sense: not affecting or related to each other
senses.dict_examp: I asked him to turn his music down on three separate occasions.
senses.lear_examp: She went to Lisbon, and we ended up living separate lives.

senses.sense: to divide into parts, or to make something divide into parts
senses.dict_examp: I separated the class into three groups.
senses.lear_examp: Recently a new system has been introduced which enables us to separate the different kinds of waste, such as plastics, organics and batteries.

senses.sense: to move apart, or to make people move apart
senses.dict_examp: I'll have to separate you two if you don't stop talking.
senses.lear_examp: I noticed that there were some people fighting, and we tried to separate them.

senses.sense: to start to live in a different place from your husband or wife because the relationship has ended
senses.dict_examp: My parents separated when I was four.
senses.lear_examp: But his parents separated and John didn't see his mother again, as well as his sister, after that day.

senses.sense: A serious problem or situation is bad and makes people worry.
senses.dict_examp: a serious illness
senses.lear_examp: As you know I have got a serious problem with my eyes.

senses.sense: not joking or intended to be funny
senses.dict_examp: Please don't laugh - I'm being serious.
senses.lear_examp: We are taught how to act in both comic and serious parts.

senses.sense: A serious person does not laugh often.
senses.dict_examp: I remember her as a very serious child.
senses.lear_examp: Well, the new teacher is very serious, but this is ok.

senses.sense: needing or deserving your complete attention
senses.dict_examp: That's an interesting job offer - I'd give it some serious consideration if I were you.
senses.lear_examp: I think it would be worthwhile to give serious thought to these animals.

senses.sense: someone who works and lives in someone else's house doing their cooking and cleaning, especially in the past
senses.dict_examp: They employed more than 50 servants.
senses.lear_examp: In this book, the author includes a detailed description of the two main characters: the rich English master PHILEAS FOGG and his French servant PASSEPARTOUT.

senses.sense: a feeling of being calm and happy
senses.dict_examp: She sat there with an air of serenity about her.
senses.lear_examp: She strongly believes that art brings peace, harmony, serenity and tranquility in their life, which could balance their emotions and help them to overcome difficulties.

senses.sense: a general feeling, attitude, or opinion about something
senses.dict_examp: nationalist/religious sentiments
senses.lear_examp: We would discuss for hours on end, arguing most of the times, and never express our true inner sentiments.

senses.sense: showing kind feelings such as sympathy, love, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a sentimental song
senses.lear_examp: I do love Lighthouse Family's music - the sentimental lyrics and catchy tunes all flow with the black singer's magic voice.

senses.sense: related to feelings and memories and not related to how much money something costs
senses.dict_examp: It wasn't an expensive ring but it had great sentimental  value.
senses.lear_examp: It can be the value in money that makes people be attached to a possession or, rather, a sentimental or symbolic link.

senses.sense: happening in parts that follow one after another in order or over time
senses.dict_examp: a serial drama/novel/story
senses.lear_examp: As a cartoonist, Aoyama originally started to draw short stories for the entertainment pages of local newspapers.  However, an editor recognized his talent, and sponsored him to create, and draw some longer, serial stories.

senses.sense: describes a person who repeatedly commits the same crime, often using the same method, or a serious crime that is committed repeatedly by one person
senses.dict_examp: She wrote a thriller about a brutal serial killer.
senses.lear_examp: These pictures have never been broadcast because too many important people are involved in these serial killings.

senses.sense: a story in a magazine or on television or radio that is told in separate parts over a period of time
senses.dict_examp: I'm watching a serial set in Yorkshire.
senses.lear_examp: As I have already mentioned the quality of the English language used is exceptional and I would like to congratulate all the people that take part in the serial.

senses.sense: badly or severely
senses.dict_examp: seriously ill/worried
senses.lear_examp: She is seriously ill with cancer.

senses.sense: in a way that shows that you are not joking
senses.dict_examp: Seriously now, did he really say that or are you just being silly?
senses.lear_examp: Seriously, Tom, I have noticed that you get angry very easily since your examinations started.

senses.sense: to consider a person, subject or situation to be important or dangerous and worth your attention or respect

senses.lear_examp: I hope you take my suggestions seriously.

senses.sense: a system or organization that provides something that people need

senses.lear_examp: I told him to phone the after-sales service.

senses.sense: when people help you and bring you things in a place such as a restaurant or hotel

senses.sense: an amount of money charged for serving a customer in a restaurant, which is often paid directly to the waiter

senses.lear_examp: The thing which annoyed me the most was that they have a 20% service charge, but I refused to pay it because there was no service.

senses.sense: a government department that is responsible for a particular area of activity

senses.sense: the time you spend working for an organization

senses.sense: a period of time or a meeting arranged for a particular activity

senses.sense: a central computer from which other computers get information

senses.sense: calm and quiet

senses.sense: the ninth month of the year, after August and before October
senses.dict_examp: the 23rd of September/September 23(rd)
senses.lear_examp: My course started in September.

senses.sense: a part of a movie or video game that shows one thing that happens
senses.dict_examp: I particularly enjoyed the dream sequence.
senses.lear_examp: However, the rest of the game is not as polished as the opening sequence: indeed, it seems that the developers simply re-used the graphical engine of the prequel, without even revamping it: the result is truly disappointing.

senses.sense: a series of related events or things that have a particular order

senses.sense: the order that events or things should happen or be arranged in

senses.lear_examp: It was the fourth summer in sequence that he had chosen this hotel to spend his holiday but this he had never experienced before.

senses.sense: not together
senses.dict_examp: Detectives interviewed the men separately.
senses.lear_examp: They were living separately and missing each other.

senses.sense: to give someone food or drink, especially guests or customers in a restaurant or bar
senses.dict_examp: Do they serve brunch on the weekend?
senses.lear_examp: We ate a lot because my mom served many kinds of food at my party.

senses.sense: to be useful as something

senses.lear_examp: As for replanting, it will serve to rejuvenate our forests around Agrinio.

senses.sense: to do work that helps society, for example in an organization such as the army or the government
senses.dict_examp: to serve in the army

senses.sense: to be in prison for a period of time

senses.lear_examp: It all came to me in prison where I was serving a two-year sentence.

senses.sense: when two or more people or things are separated

senses.sense: the decision of two people who were married to stop living together
senses.dict_examp: They decided on a trial separation.
senses.lear_examp: We lived for a time in peace but our happiness ceased because of his jealousy and fear of losing me, which was the cause of our daylong quarrels. There was no solution apart from separation.

senses.sense: a group of words, usually containing a verb, that expresses a complete idea

senses.lear_examp: Every lesson, I read and write loads of sentences.

senses.sense: a punishment that a judge gives to someone who has committed a crime

senses.lear_examp: This is even worse than a real life sentence.

senses.sense: to give a punishment to someone who has committed a crime
senses.dict_examp: He was sentenced to 3 months in jail and fined $5000.
senses.lear_examp: Soon afterwards he gets imprisoned again and is sentenced to death. Sydney takes his place and is executed instead of him.

senses.sense: 7th written as a word
senses.dict_examp: It's the seventh (of May) today.
senses.lear_examp: The day of the art class is the seventh of May.

senses.sense: a problem that makes something happen later or more slowly than it should

senses.lear_examp: A strong bond between you and your friends, with whom you can have discussions about personal setbacks, is another very vital point.

senses.sense: the payment of money that is owed
senses.dict_examp: We enclose a check in settlement of your claim.

senses.sense: an official agreement that finishes an argument
senses.dict_examp: a peace settlement
senses.lear_examp: All employees working for the public transport went on strike a week ago, and there is no settlement in sight.

senses.sense: an arrangement to end a disagreement without taking it to a court of law
senses.dict_examp: They reached an out-of-court settlement.
senses.lear_examp: Hoping for a settlement without having to involve the courts, I remain.

senses.sense: a town or village which people built to live in after arriving from somewhere else
senses.dict_examp: An isolated settlement far from the big city.
senses.lear_examp: The traditional style of small living communities in tribes cannot be sustained, since the farmlands around a settlement cannot provide the people with sufficient food and work.

senses.sense: the number 70
senses.dict_examp: sixty, seventy, eighty
senses.lear_examp: I have bought new shoes.  I bought them because there were very beautiful, and they cost only seventy dollars.

senses.sense: to be aged between 70 and 79

senses.lear_examp: After some minutes, an old man in his late seventies opened the door and told us in his trembling voice that Daisy wasn't at home.

senses.sense: the years 1970 through 1979
senses.dict_examp: I grew up in the seventies.
senses.lear_examp: The nineties is, indeed, a reverse of the seventies.

senses.sense: the number 7
senses.dict_examp: The restaurant opens for dinner at seven o'clock.
senses.lear_examp: Tomorrow I'll finish my work at six o'clock, so I think that I'll can arrive your home at seven o'clock.

senses.sense: the number 17
senses.dict_examp: sixteen, seventeen, eighteen
senses.lear_examp: He is seventeen years old.

senses.sense: some, but not a lot
senses.dict_examp: I've seen "Gone with the Wind" several times.
senses.lear_examp: I also got several books, a beautiful bag, a T-shirt, etc.

senses.sense: the position of a house or other building
senses.dict_examp: Their cottage is in a beautiful rural setting.
senses.lear_examp: It is a beautiful setting with old architecture, trees and glittering water.

senses.sense: the time and the place in which the action of a book, movie, play, etc. happens
senses.dict_examp: The play has its setting in a wartime prison camp.
senses.lear_examp: The setting of "The Third Man" is Vienna after the Second World War.

senses.sense: If you settle an argument, you solve the problem and stop arguing.
senses.dict_examp: My father and I have agreed finally to settle our differences.
senses.lear_examp: Caroline and her husband had had an argument last week, but as he was going to be away for a few days, they had finally settled their differences.

senses.sense: to start living somewhere that you are going to live for a long time
senses.dict_examp: After they got married, they settled in Kentucky.
senses.lear_examp: I can understand why you have decided to settle near the Loire Valley, which is one of the greatest parts of France.

senses.sense: to decide or arrange something

senses.lear_examp: I really hope it will not take you long to settle the matter.

senses.sense: to move to a lower level and stay there
senses.dict_examp: The house had been empty for years, and dust had settled on all the surfaces.
senses.lear_examp: Whenever I have cleaned my shelves you can just watch the dust settle on them.

senses.sense: If you settle a bill or a debt, you pay the money that you owe.
senses.dict_examp: I've got some bills to settle.
senses.lear_examp: Many individuals are caught overspending when they check their credit card statements, later having to borrow from money lenders to settle their bills.

senses.sense: to become familiar with a place and to feel happy and confident in it

senses.lear_examp: He seemed to be such a nice guy and I was very happy to find you have settled down so well in your new life.

senses.sense: to start living in a place where you intend to stay for a long time
senses.dict_examp: Eventually I'd like to settle down and have a family, but not yet.
senses.lear_examp: I guess the changes occur once the young couple decides to marry and settle down.

senses.sense: to become quiet and calm, or to make someone quiet and calm

senses.lear_examp: You should welcome your relatives, make them settle down and ask them to wait a moment.

senses.sense: to begin to feel relaxed and happy in a new home or job

senses.lear_examp: After you settle in, you'll find there's a lot of ways to save money on food.

senses.sense: to put plates, knives, forks, etc. on the table to prepare for a meal

senses.lear_examp: We set the table and waited for Jun. He was supposed to come around six.

senses.sense: If a story, movie, etc. is set in a particular time or place, the action in it happens in that time or place.
senses.dict_examp: "West Side Story" is set in New York in the late 1950s.
senses.lear_examp: It was an adventure story and I liked it a lot because it was set in Australia.

senses.sense: to fix a date or time for something

senses.lear_examp: I'm going to miss your class tomorrow, but we can set a date to cover the work on.

senses.sense: When the sun sets, it moves down in the sky until it cannot be seen.
senses.dict_examp: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
senses.lear_examp: I loved the thin fog before the sun set.

senses.sense: to make a piece of equipment ready to be used
senses.dict_examp: The dishwasher is set to go on in two hours.

senses.lear_examp: The camp is set in a beautiful place in the heart of nature, with lots of opportunities to get out of the camp if you want to.

senses.sense: to cause something or someone to be in the stated condition or situation

senses.lear_examp: It sets a good example for other museums.

senses.sense: to establish the best achievement so far in a sport or competition

senses.sense: to decide the level of something

senses.lear_examp: We set off for home at 5 o'clock.

senses.sense: to cause something to begin or happen, especially a loud noise or a lot of activity

senses.lear_examp: He would set off the smoke alarm by lighting some of his matches.

senses.sense: to begin a trip

senses.lear_examp: Next morning I packed my luggage and set out on our trip to France.

senses.sense: a group of things that belong together

senses.sense: a part of a game of tennis

senses.sense: the place where a movie or play is performed or recorded, and the furniture, pictures, etc. that are used
senses.dict_examp: a movie set
senses.lear_examp: Her father, John, was a stuntperson and he died in an unfortunate accident while he was performing on a film set.

senses.sense: to be ready

senses.lear_examp: So, there you go. I'm all set!

senses.sense: fixed and never changing

senses.sense: If you describe something as a shame, you are disappointed that it has happened.

senses.sense: when you feel embarrassed and guilty about something bad that you have done

senses.lear_examp: It destroys the individual, brings shame to his family, and is a liability instead of an asset to his society.

senses.sense: attractive or exciting in a sexual way
senses.dict_examp: sexy underwear
senses.lear_examp: Richard was only wearing Levis Jeans and a white T shirt but looked so sexy and handsome.

senses.sense: how severe something is

senses.lear_examp: In conclusion, we have to accept the severity of the environmental damage, but we should not give up our hopes for a better future.

senses.sense: shocked and upset
senses.dict_examp: They were not injured in the accident, but they were badly shaken.
senses.lear_examp: After that encounter with her old classmate she felt shaken and upset.

senses.sense: relating to the activity of sex
senses.dict_examp: a sexual relationship
senses.lear_examp: Before continuing with the story I would like to remind you that having sexual relationships was common to everybody in Brave New World.

senses.sense: relating to being male or female
senses.dict_examp: He’s always believed in sexual equality.
senses.lear_examp: But we must not forget that there is still sexual discrimination when women apply for jobs higher up in a hierarchy.

senses.sense: a dark area made by something that is stopping the light

senses.lear_examp: Suddenly I saw a shadow and as I turned over I noticed that something was moving in the trees.

senses.sense: If something is true beyond a shadow of a doubt, it is certainly true.
senses.dict_examp: He stole the money, without a shadow of a doubt.
senses.lear_examp: It is beyond the shadow of a doubt that Douglas does not offer her this kind of life.

senses.sense: the state of being either male or female
senses.dict_examp: What sex is your cat?
senses.lear_examp: The teacher gave me the application form about my name, age, sex, nationality and address.

senses.sense: sexual activity between people
senses.dict_examp: She was complaining about all the sex and violence on television.
senses.lear_examp: I hate watching soap operas and thrillers, because they contain too much violence and sex.

senses.sense: people who are the other sex from you
senses.dict_examp: When you attend an all girls or all boys school, you don't study with members of the opposite sex.
senses.lear_examp: This is not only about trying to impress (preferably) a person of the opposite sex, but fashion also gives you a great chance to express yourself.

senses.sense: a liquid substance that you use to wash your hair
senses.dict_examp: an anti-dandruff shampoo
senses.lear_examp: I think the soap and the shampoo are in the bathroom.

senses.sense: to have or use something at the same time as someone else
senses.dict_examp: Bill and I shared an office for years.
senses.lear_examp: There are two beds because I share my room with a friend.

senses.sense: to divide something between two or more people
senses.dict_examp: Do you want to a piece of pie with me?
senses.lear_examp: We shared one big cake.

senses.sense: If two or more people or things share a feeling, quality or experience, they both or all have the same feeling, quality or experience.
senses.dict_examp: We share an interest in sailing.
senses.lear_examp: Her name is Gulia and I met her at the University. She is very nice, and we share many interests, so we gave each other our phone numbers.

senses.sense: If two or more people share an activity, they each do some of it.
senses.dict_examp: It’s a long trip – why don’t we share the driving
senses.lear_examp: Ask your employer and other colleagues to share the work.

senses.sense: to tell someone your problems/thoughts/ideas, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Would you like to share your thoughts with the group, Donald?
senses.lear_examp: I have received your letter asking for my opinion about the Conference and have decided to write and share some of my thoughts.

senses.sense: a part of something that has been divided
senses.dict_examp: The total bill for the three of us comes to $90, so your share is $30.

senses.sense: a lot of something and enough of it, usually something bad
senses.dict_examp: We've had our fair share of rain already this summer.
senses.lear_examp: It wasn't as if Jean hadn't seen his fair share of dead bodies, but these ones were far more, well, disgusting, than anything before.

senses.sense: one of the equal parts that the value of a company is divided into when it is owned by a group of people
senses.dict_examp: She wants to buy shares of stock in that company.
senses.lear_examp: It is no longer the consumer but the shareholder who must be kept happy, in order to keep the share price high, and the simple worker pays the price.

senses.sense: not deep
senses.dict_examp: The stream was quite shallow so we were able to walk across it.
senses.lear_examp: A  heavy body plunged into the shallow water of harbor No 14.

senses.sense: not showing any interest in serious ideas
senses.dict_examp: He is a very shallow person.
senses.lear_examp: She is shallow and superficial, and she finds it hard to relate to her husband.

senses.sense: extremely bad
senses.dict_examp: a severe chest infection/leg injury/toothache
senses.lear_examp: Their life was a severe financial struggle, and Tom's dream was to run somewhere far away.

senses.sense: a severe person is unfriendly or very strict
senses.dict_examp: She had her hair tied back in a severe style.
senses.lear_examp: Jane Eyre is sent away to a school for orphans. ... The atmosphere in school is no better, with little food and severe teachers.

senses.sense: to move backward and forward or up and down in quick, short movements, or to make something or someone do this
senses.dict_examp: A young boy climbed into the apple tree and shook the branches so that the fruit fell down.
senses.lear_examp: I was getting nervous and my hands began to shake.

senses.sense: to hold someone's hand and move it up and down when you meet them for the first time, or when you make an agreement with them
senses.dict_examp: The two leaders smiled and shook hands for the photographers.
senses.lear_examp: I felt embarrassed when all my friends thought they were my friends, so they all shook hands with them except me.

senses.sense: If you are shaking, your body makes quick short movements, or you feel as if it is doing so, because you are frightened or nervous.
senses.dict_examp: She was shaking as she opened the letter.
senses.lear_examp: She understood that it was absolutely foolish of her to stand there shaking with fear.

senses.sense: to move your head from side to side to mean "no"
senses.dict_examp: I asked him if he wanted to come and he just shook his head.
senses.lear_examp: He just looked at me shaking his head and got into his car and drove off.

senses.sense: If your voice shakes, you sound very nervous or frightened.
senses.dict_examp: He looked pale, and his voice shook as he spoke.
senses.lear_examp: "Excuse me, my name is Heathcliff Moore, I'm a musician," he approached the owner with shaking voice.

senses.sense: to get rid of an illness, something unpleasant, or something that is causing you problems
senses.dict_examp: I hope I can shake off this cold before the weekend.
senses.lear_examp: He was capable of shaking off the criticism due to the fact that he believed strongly enough in himself, which I find quite remarkable.

senses.sense: to cause large changes in something
senses.dict_examp: Technological changes have shaken up many industries.
senses.lear_examp: I believe that their aim is to shake up public opinion in the most impressive way they can.

senses.sense: If an unpleasant experience shakes someone up, it makes them feel shocked and upset.
senses.dict_examp: The accident really shook him up.

senses.sense: the activity of joining pieces of cloth together or repairing them with a needle and thread
senses.dict_examp: I'm not very good at sewing.
senses.lear_examp: I especially cherish the idea of finding myself in Camelot being a lady in waiting to Queen Guinevere - to spend my days reading, sewing, embroidering, learning about far off places and discoveries, adventures and the latest gossip from the court.

senses.sense: the physical form of something made by the line around its outer edge
senses.dict_examp: a circular/rectangular shape
senses.lear_examp: Well, it looks like yours, you know, the same size and shape.

senses.sense: in good/bad, etc. health or condition
senses.dict_examp: She runs every day so she's in great shape.
senses.lear_examp: I am of the opinion that if you are in good shape and the distance is not too much, you should leave the car at home and use the bike.

senses.sense: to stay healthy and physically strong
senses.dict_examp: It's important to keep in shape.
senses.lear_examp: We want to keep in shape, and we are interested in a gym - do you have one or is there one close to there?

senses.sense: many different types of people or things

senses.lear_examp: I don't like showing my I.D. card every morning.

senses.sense: to give information in a book, on a website, on a piece of equipment, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The pictures show two different sports. Talk to your partner about which you would prefer and why.
senses.lear_examp: So it would be very kind of you to send me an information sheet or a brochure about your club and a timetable which shows the courses and the meetings.

senses.sense: to teach someone how to do something by explaining it or by doing it yourself while they watch
senses.dict_examp: She showed me how to use the new bookkeeping program.
senses.lear_examp: Before the performance I brought the spectators to their seats and then an instructor showed me how to operate the spotlights.

senses.sense: If numbers, results, facts, etc. show something, they prove that it is true.
senses.dict_examp: Research shows that 40 percent of the program's viewers are aged over 55.
senses.lear_examp: Experiments have even shown some astonishing results, that apes for example have the same abilities as humans.

senses.sense: to express a feeling so that other people are able to notice it
senses.dict_examp: He finds it difficult to show affection.
senses.lear_examp: I think a face can show so much and some day I hope I could become a photographer.

senses.sense: to be easy or possible to see, or to make something easy or possible to see
senses.dict_examp: The sadness really shows on her face.
senses.lear_examp: Their hair was turning gray and their faces showed the first wrinkles.

senses.sense: to go with someone and show them a place
senses.dict_examp: Alejandro offered to show her around Mexico City.
senses.lear_examp: I can take a few days off work and show you around the city.

senses.sense: to try to make people admire your abilities or achievements in a way which other people find annoying
senses.dict_examp: She only bought that sports car to show off and prove she could afford one.
senses.lear_examp: You can even show off a bit to your relatives and friends.

senses.sense: to arrive somewhere
senses.dict_examp: I invited him for eight o'clock, but he didn't show up until nine-thirty.
senses.lear_examp: I took him to his father and then my friend, Maria, showed up.

senses.sense: a television or radio program or a theater performance
senses.dict_examp: a TV show
senses.lear_examp: You can see lots of traditional shows there, it will be very interesting for you.

senses.sense: an event at which a group of similar things are brought together for the public to see
senses.dict_examp: a fashion/flower show
senses.lear_examp: I do not know if it is possible to make any changes,  but we saw an ad in "Time Out" magazine last week about a fashion show which we would like to see.

senses.sense: being shown to the public
senses.dict_examp: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
senses.lear_examp: One of the facilities that really makes a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library.

senses.sense: a sister or brother
senses.dict_examp: I have three siblings.
senses.lear_examp: I am also lucky to have a sibling, an older sister, who took great care of me when we were children.

senses.sense: another effect that a drug has on your body in addition to the main effect for which the doctor has given you the drug
senses.dict_examp: Headaches are one side effect of this drug.
senses.lear_examp: Now, we have come up with something called Phyto essence that is designed to overcome skin problems effectively without causing any harmful side effects.

senses.sense: an extra result of a situation, especially one that you did not plan or expect
senses.dict_examp: One side effect of getting a new job is that I can cycle to work and I've lost a lot of weight.
senses.lear_examp: They seem to neglect the growing rate of unemployment and its possible side effects.

senses.sense: the act of washing yourself while standing under a flow of water
senses.dict_examp: I want to take a quick shower before we go out.
senses.lear_examp: I have to wake up at 7.30 AM. I run to the bathroom to take a shower.

senses.sense: a piece of bathroom equipment that you stand under to wash your whole body
senses.dict_examp: He likes to sing in the shower.
senses.lear_examp: And there are showers and a sauna you will be able to use any time after the gym.

senses.sense: a short period of rain or light snow
senses.dict_examp: thunder showers
senses.lear_examp: Well the weather was really good during the morning but there were  some showers during the afternoon.

senses.sense: to wash standing under a shower
senses.dict_examp: We all showered before breakfast.
senses.lear_examp: Around six o'clock, she finally got up, showered, had breakfast and set off to work.

senses.sense: to give someone a lot of presents, praise, etc.
senses.dict_examp: He showered her with expensive gifts.
senses.lear_examp: As time passes the children start to see a pattern developing, every time that they request time or attention they are showered with expensive clothes or toys to compensate for the lack of it.

senses.sense: when you are sick
senses.dict_examp: I get motion sickness on a boat and sometimes on a plane, too.
senses.lear_examp: The simple joy and happiness will help you to feel in good shape and keep away any sickness.

senses.sense: to shake, usually because you are thinking of something unpleasant
senses.dict_examp: The sight of so much blood made him shudder.
senses.lear_examp: She shuddered at the memory.

senses.sense: to close something, or to become closed
senses.dict_examp: Would you shut the door, please?
senses.lear_examp: The doors shut by themselves.

senses.sense: If a computer or machine shuts down or someone shuts it down, it stops operating.
senses.dict_examp: Make sure you shut down your computer before you leave.
senses.lear_examp: I was as happy as a lark. I shut down the computer and I called my mom to tell her about the good news.

senses.sense: If a business or organization shuts down or someone shuts it down, it closes.
senses.dict_examp: The company plans to shut down four assembly plants and cut 10,000 jobs.
senses.lear_examp: A great number of zoos ought to be shut down.

senses.sense: to stop talking or making a noise, or to make someone do this
senses.dict_examp: I wish you'd shut up for a minute and listen to what the rest of us have to say.
senses.lear_examp: You must still remember that time we walked along the street, singing blues and rock, it's incredible the way that people shouted at us to shut up.

senses.sense: closed
senses.dict_examp: Her office door was shut all day.

senses.sense: to not talk about something
senses.dict_examp: If you don't keep your mouth shut, there'll be trouble.
senses.lear_examp: She made every effort to keep her mouth shut but it disturbed her to be the only one to know the truth, apart from her brother.

senses.sense: the state of being shy
senses.dict_examp: When I met the movie star, I was overcome with shyness.
senses.lear_examp: Some of them were encouraged by their work-fellows to overcome their initial shyness.

senses.sense: not confident, especially about meeting or talking to new people
senses.dict_examp: He was too shy to ask her to dance with him.
senses.lear_examp: I was a little shy at first, but I ended up talking too much!

senses.sense: not feeling well, or suffering from a disease
senses.dict_examp: a sick child
senses.lear_examp: Everybody went except Natalie because she was sick.

senses.sense: to be bored with or annoyed about something that has been happening for a long time
senses.dict_examp: I'm sick of people telling me how to run my life.
senses.lear_examp: Michael was sick of seeing the same story happen all over again.

senses.sense: cruel and unpleasant
senses.dict_examp: He's got a sick mind.
senses.lear_examp: Her sick mind was obsessed with the impunity that criminals were treated with at trials and with the corrupted judges that hold those trials, and decided she would kill all of them and put an end to the impunity.

senses.sense: likely to vomit
senses.dict_examp: I feel sick to my stomach.

senses.sense: good at judging situations and making decisions which give you an advantage
senses.dict_examp: a shrewd politician
senses.lear_examp: It was only much later that I realized what a shrewd investment on my parent's part this had been.

senses.sense: a bus, train, plane, etc. which travels regularly between two places, usually a short distance
senses.dict_examp: the Boston-New York shuttle
senses.lear_examp: I am convinced that a center with less traffic and more pedestrianized areas will attract more other people. Especially if there is a parking opportunity outside of the center with well-organised shuttle buses to the center.

senses.sense: a small sea animal that you can eat, and which has a shell and ten legs
senses.dict_examp: The grilled shrimp is delicious!
senses.lear_examp: It has great food: fish, grilled meat, shrimp and delicious cakes and cookies.

senses.sense: one of the two parts that something would divide into if you drew a line down the middle
senses.dict_examp: He likes to sleep on the right side of the bed.
senses.lear_examp: It's an interesting place because the Lake has a road through which cars can go to the other side of the Lake.

senses.sense: a flat outer surface of an object, especially one that is not the top or the bottom
senses.dict_examp: The names of ships are usually painted on their sides.
senses.lear_examp: It cost 152 Euro. It's black with silver stripes on the sides.

senses.sense: an edge or border of something
senses.dict_examp: A square has four sides.
senses.lear_examp: We are going to paint one side of the room orange and the others white.

senses.sense: the area next to something
senses.dict_examp: I have a small table at/by the side of  my bed.
senses.lear_examp: Linda is by my side right now and she asks me to send you a warm hug.

senses.sense: part of a situation that can be considered or dealt with separately
senses.dict_examp: She looks after the financial side of things.
senses.lear_examp: Finally, I think for me the most important thing is to enjoy life - don't be worried about little things and always find the funny side of each situation.

senses.sense: a part of someone's character
senses.dict_examp: She has a very practical side.
senses.lear_examp: In fact the film describes the actions of this politician, also saying something not very "Politically Correct", but true: he reveals that no one is always good, everyone has a dark hidden side.

senses.sense: If two things or people are side by side, they are next to each other.
senses.dict_examp: We sat side by side on the sofa.
senses.lear_examp: It is not rare to see two people walking side by side, both talking on the phone.

senses.sense: If something moves from side to side, it moves from left to right and back again repeatedly.
senses.dict_examp: swinging from side to side
senses.lear_examp: I began to understand it when I went to Kenya in 1986, because I had the wonderful chance to look at the animals in their natural surroundings, without being in a cage, walking nervously from side to side.

senses.sense: one of the people or groups who are arguing, fighting, or competing
senses.dict_examp: Whose side is he on?
senses.lear_examp: I hope you'll be on my side.

senses.sense: a way of considering something, especially when there is disagreement about it
senses.dict_examp: There are at least two sides to every question.
senses.lear_examp: This shows the other side of technology.

senses.sense: to find good things in a bad situation
senses.dict_examp: Look on the bright side - no one was badly hurt.
senses.lear_examp: I am quite self-confident and I usually look on the bright side, as I am not interested in pessimistic thoughts.

senses.sense: A food served on the side is served separate from the other foods.
senses.dict_examp: I’ll have the salad with the dressing on the side.
senses.lear_examp: A common meal in my country will include soup and rice, a main dish is usually served with beans on the side and corn tortillas, all this is full of vitamins and calcium.

senses.sense: to not use or deal with something now, but keep it for a later time
senses.dict_examp: She put the papers to one side, intending to read them later.

senses.sense: in addition to your main job
senses.dict_examp: She does some freelance work on the side.
senses.lear_examp: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side.

senses.sense: the part of your family who are either your mother's relatives or your father's relatives
senses.dict_examp: They tend to be tall on my mother's side of the family.
senses.lear_examp: Both on my father's side as well as on my mother's side of the family we formed a close knit group.

senses.sense: the two areas of your body from under your arms to the tops of your legs
senses.dict_examp: Stand with your arms by your sides.

senses.sense: If you have someone at/by your side, they support you and help you.
senses.dict_examp: With Dan at my side, I felt I could do anything.
senses.lear_examp: She really needed someone by her side, someone to lean on and share her worries.

senses.sense: to become smaller, or to make something smaller
senses.dict_examp: Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.
senses.lear_examp: After 5 seconds I started shrinking until I was as small as the smallest toe on my foot.

senses.sense: the importance or meaning of something
senses.dict_examp: I still don't understand the significance of his remark.
senses.lear_examp: In spite of the progress achieved in promoting the social status of women, one should not overestimate the significance of these achievements to ordinary women's careers.

senses.sense: a valuable, shiny, gray-white metal used to make coins and jewelry
senses.dict_examp: We gave Alison and Tom a dish made of solid silver as a wedding present.
senses.lear_examp: It was a beautiful ring, it was made of silver with a diamond on it.

senses.sense: made of silver, or of the color of silver
senses.dict_examp: a silver ring
senses.lear_examp: I got beautiful presents, but my favorite is a silver ring.

senses.sense: a symbol or message in a public place that gives information or instructions
senses.dict_examp: a stop sign
senses.lear_examp: And it is easy to get there, just follow the sign.

senses.sense: something which shows that something is happening or that it exists or is true
senses.dict_examp: Flowers are the first sign of spring.
senses.lear_examp: The bride and the groom meet at the church because it's a bad sign if the groom sees the bride before the ceremony.

senses.sense: a movement you make to give someone information or tell them what to do
senses.dict_examp: She pointed to her watch as a sign that it was getting late and she wanted to leave.
senses.lear_examp: She looked at Paul and made a strange sign with her fingers.

senses.sense: a written or printed mark which has a standard meaning
senses.dict_examp: + and - are mathematical signs.

senses.sense: If there is no sign of someone or something, you cannot see them.
senses.dict_examp: By eight o'clock, there was still no sign of Janne.
senses.lear_examp: He was supposed to come on Wednesday just like you told me but there was no sign of him.

senses.sense: to write your name on something to show that you created it or to show that you agree to it
senses.dict_examp: to sign a letter/form/check/contract/agreement
senses.lear_examp: It was signed "Fat Boy".

senses.sense: to arrange to take part in an organized activity
senses.dict_examp: I've signed up for evening classes at the community college.
senses.lear_examp: If you are interested in other activities, just sign up for them on the notice board.

senses.sense: a type of cloth which is light and smooth
senses.dict_examp: a silk dress
senses.lear_examp: Normally, I would prefer my blouses to be made of cotton or silk, as these materials make me feel comfortable.

senses.sense: the ability to see
senses.dict_examp: If your sight is poor, you should not drive a car.
senses.lear_examp: She had lost her sight although doctors didn't know if it was forever.

senses.sense: places of interest, especially to visitors
senses.dict_examp: We spent a two weeks in Rome looking at all the sights.
senses.lear_examp: I have many plans, I want to show you all the remarkable sights in Georgia.

senses.sense: when you see someone or something
senses.dict_examp: I faint at the sight of my own blood.
senses.lear_examp: Just think; drinking our cold beers against the sight of the pounding waves and feeling the wind on our faces.

senses.sense: the area that it is possible for you to see
senses.dict_examp: Keep your bags in sight at all times.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Editor, This morning when I opened my newspaper, my eyes caught sight of an article called "Failure of festival", and I read it.

senses.sense: when you fall in love with someone the first time you meet
senses.dict_examp: We were happened to be seated at the same table, and it was love at first sight!
senses.lear_examp: We had first met the spring before and it was love at first sight.

senses.sense: when you first see or hear about something or someone
senses.dict_examp: It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
senses.lear_examp: I must admit that, at first sight, I did not feel like reading it, but later I made up my mind and decided to accept your invitation.

senses.sense: to forget about an important idea or fact because you are thinking too much about other, less important things
senses.dict_examp: We mustn't lose sight of the original aims of this project.
senses.lear_examp: Little do we realize that in the process we lose sight of the fundamentals, which in this case is the protection of our environment.

senses.sense: to decide to achieve something
senses.dict_examp: She's set her sights on becoming a doctor.
senses.lear_examp: This resemblance was the final silent argument that convinced Wormold to promise Milly the expensive and beautiful horse she had set her sights on.

senses.sense: to see something suddenly, often only for a short time
senses.dict_examp: He caught sight of himself in the mirror.
senses.lear_examp: All we could see were people bursting into tears when they caught sight of his coffin.

senses.sense: when two things or people are similar, or a way in which they are similar
senses.dict_examp: I can see the similarity between you and your mother.
senses.lear_examp: Another similarity between the two was their appearance.

senses.sense: when there is no sound
senses.dict_examp: The three men ate in silence.
senses.lear_examp: It isn't too big and it's quiet enough and I like it so much because of the silence and the beauty of this place.

senses.sense: a period of time in which there is complete quiet or no speaking
senses.dict_examp: There were long silences during the discussion.
senses.lear_examp: The progress of the story is very slow, but the author is describing hard conditions, hard characters and long silences, which is quite typical of his way of writing.

senses.sense: a period of time when someone says nothing about a particular subject or when someone does not communicate with someone at all
senses.dict_examp: She ended her silence yesterday and spoke to a TV reporter about the accident.
senses.lear_examp: How dared he call her after such a long silence and order her what to do?

senses.sense: a path with a hard surface along one or both sides of a street that people walk on
senses.dict_examp: The sidewalk was blocked by a fallen tree branch.
senses.lear_examp: When I was crossing the road I suddenly saw a beautiful woman on the opposite sidewalk.

senses.sense: important or noticeable
senses.dict_examp: There has been a significant increase in the number of women students in recent years.
senses.lear_examp: One of the most significant inventions is the computer.

senses.sense: the activity of visiting places that are interesting because they are historic, famous, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Did you do much sightseeing while you were in Paris?
senses.lear_examp: I'd like to go sightseeing and eat Italian food.

senses.sense: without any sound
senses.dict_examp: The empty house was completely silent.
senses.lear_examp: The countryside, like Chianti, is peaceful and silent.

senses.sense: without talking
senses.dict_examp: I have remained silent till now, Mike, but I have to tell you what I think.
senses.lear_examp: When they were there, Aunt Patience was obliged by her husband to go to her room and remain silent.

senses.sense: in a similar way
senses.dict_examp: The children were similarly dressed.
senses.lear_examp: For instance, in northeast China, Australian visitors can learn the specific tea culture from local people. ... Similarly, Chinese visitors can know the Australian wine culture by visiting the wineries.

senses.sense: without making any noise
senses.dict_examp: She wept silently as she read the letter.
senses.lear_examp: After waiting silently for two minutes, she dropped the phone.

senses.sense: in a direction to the left or right, not forward or backward
senses.dict_examp: The fence is leaning sideways.
senses.lear_examp: Unaware of all the sideways glances and chatter that paused as she passed, she headed back toward the river.

senses.sense: to make something less complicated and therefore easier to do or understand
senses.dict_examp: the new, simplified tax system
senses.lear_examp: The technology has probably simplified life in a way that no one could believe was possible about 20 years ago.

senses.sense: If something or someone is similar to another thing or person, they have many things the same, although they are not exactly the same.
senses.dict_examp: My father and I have similar views on politics.
senses.lear_examp: I can understand how you are feeling because at our age, every teenager has similar problems.

senses.sense: knives, forks, and spoons
senses.dict_examp: Do we have enough silverware for twelve people?
senses.lear_examp: All the tablecloths are white and the silverware is beautiful.

senses.sense: your name written by yourself, always in the same way, usually to show that something has been written or agreed by you
senses.dict_examp: Please put your signature in this box.
senses.lear_examp: I thought it was a joke but when I saw the signature I knew it was for real.

senses.sense: easy to do or to understand
senses.dict_examp: The instructions were written in simple English.
senses.lear_examp: If you need some help, I can help you with the organization of the titles and other simple things.

senses.sense: plain or not complicated
senses.dict_examp: a simple life
senses.lear_examp: You can eat simple food and drink good local wine.

senses.sense: used to describe the one important fact, truth, etc.
senses.dict_examp: We didn't go swimming for the simple reason that the water was too cold.
senses.lear_examp: There is a very simple reason for me to choose live music. I really enjoy going to  places in which you can see a good concert.

senses.sense: a sign by the side of the road that gives information about routes and distances
senses.dict_examp: There are signposts at the edge of the parking lot showing which paths lead to the lake and which to the tent sites and the camp store.
senses.lear_examp: There were no signposts and there was no one to ask where he could find a place to stay.

senses.sense: the quality of being simple
senses.dict_examp: The advantage of the plan is its simplicity.
senses.lear_examp: Video facilities are rated as quite good by the students, and computer programs have gained almost everybody's compliments for their simplicity and efficacy.

senses.sense: showing little thought or judgment
senses.dict_examp: a silly question
senses.lear_examp: They had some very silly games.

senses.sense: small and not important
senses.dict_examp: She gets upset over such silly things.
senses.lear_examp: People are so worried about silly things, about how to make money or how to be popular and they forget about what really matters.

senses.sense: the process of making something more simple
senses.dict_examp: I think these rules need some simplification.
senses.lear_examp: It might be a simplification and an exaggeration, but as the word says: "The road of excess leads to the tower of wisdom", and although the idea expresses itself in crude terms, I do think there is some truth to it.

senses.sense: used to emphasize what you are saying
senses.dict_examp: We simply don't have the time.
senses.lear_examp: That's simply unbelievable!

senses.sense: only
senses.dict_examp: A lot of people miss out on this opportunity simply because they don't know about it.
senses.lear_examp: I am very interested in fashion, simply because it is a style, an attitude, a way of life.

senses.sense: in a way that is not complicated or difficult to understand
senses.dict_examp: He explained it as simply as he could, but the class still didn't understand.
senses.lear_examp: Try to organize your work as simply as possible.

senses.sense: to breathe out slowly and noisily, often because you are annoyed or unhappy
senses.dict_examp: She sighed deeply and sat down.
senses.lear_examp: Having solid ground beneath her feet again she sighed with relief for having survived this adventure.

senses.sense: the sound that is made when someone sighs
senses.dict_examp: He read the letter and gave a deep sigh.
senses.lear_examp: I entered the house with a deep sigh!

senses.sense: a movement, light, or sound that gives information, or tells people what to do
senses.dict_examp: At a signal from their teacher, the children all held up their flags.
senses.lear_examp: The signal was given. We started side by side but soon I overtook him.

senses.sense: a series of light waves or sound waves which are sent to a radio, television, cell phone, etc.
senses.dict_examp: I can't get a phone signal here.
senses.lear_examp: On the other hand you can face problems with signal transmission.

senses.sense: to make a movement that gives information or tells people what to do
senses.dict_examp: He signaled left, then turned the truck slowly.
senses.lear_examp: He signalled his trusty and mostly silent cameraman to follow him and decided to go underground. (761364; Certificate of Proficiency in English; Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Catalan; Pass

senses.sense: to go down or make something go down below the surface of water or a soft substance and not come back up
senses.dict_examp: The Titanic was a passenger ship which sank to the bottom of the ocean in 1912.
senses.lear_examp: They were so scared that the boat would sink...

senses.sense: to move or make something move to a lower position or level
senses.dict_examp: The sun glowed red as it sank slowly below the horizon.
senses.lear_examp: Dora's face grew pale and she sank into a chair.

senses.sense: a bowl that is fixed to the wall in a kitchen or bathroom in which you wash dishes, your hands, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a bathroom/kitchen sink
senses.lear_examp: I put my watch on the sink in the bathroom.

senses.sense: not married
senses.dict_examp: a single woman/man/person
senses.lear_examp: He's 25 years old and single.

senses.sense: for only one person
senses.dict_examp: a single bed
senses.lear_examp: I am selling a single bed.

senses.sense: someone who has a child or children, but no wife or husband living with them
senses.dict_examp: Many single parents find it difficult to arrange for child care.
senses.lear_examp: She's a single parent, with 3 children from Australia.

senses.sense: used to emphasize that you are talking about each one of a group or series
senses.dict_examp: I call him every single day.
senses.lear_examp: But we used to play together every single day!

senses.sense: only one
senses.dict_examp: There was a single light in the corner of the room.
senses.lear_examp: The night was calm and not a single sound was disturbing her.

senses.sense: the number 16
senses.dict_examp: fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, seventeen
senses.lear_examp: Hi! My name is Ian and I'm sixteen years old.

senses.sense: honest and saying or showing what you really feel or believe
senses.dict_examp: He seems to be sincere.
senses.lear_examp: During these years I have also found her to be honest, sincere, hard-working and imaginative.

senses.sense: used to add emphasis when you are expressing a feeling
senses.dict_examp: The family wishes to express their sincere thanks to all the staff at the hospital.
senses.lear_examp: Again, sincere gratitude for your kind work.

senses.sense: to be in a particular place
senses.dict_examp: The hotel is situated by Lake Garda.
