senses.lear_examp: So, by the time you read this letter I'll probably be safe and sound in Liverpool.

senses.sense: to seem good, interesting, strange, etc. from what is said or written
senses.dict_examp: Your job sounds really interesting.
senses.lear_examp: How about painting the floor with white paint and the walls with black paint?  I think it sounds fun.

senses.sense: to seem like something, from what you have heard or read
senses.dict_examp: That sounds like a really good idea.
senses.lear_examp: It sounds like your new trousers are very nice.

senses.sense: to seem angry, happy, rude, etc. when you speak
senses.dict_examp: He sounded very depressed when we spoke on the telephone yesterday.
senses.lear_examp: He sounded so excited!

senses.sense: a substance made from beans and used to make many foods
senses.dict_examp: This milk is made from soy.

senses.sense: all the different ideas, opinions, possibilities, etc. that exist
senses.dict_examp: He has support from across the whole political spectrum.
senses.lear_examp: At the other end of the spectrum of opinions you can find some people who need to park in the city for business matters, like a local shopkeeper I talked to, who is afraid of losing customers.

senses.sense: the set of colors into which light can be separated
senses.dict_examp: The colors of the spectrum can be seen in a rainbow.
senses.lear_examp: Then, at dawn, the sun slowly rises, producing a spectacular spectrum of colors, ranging from deep purple to blinding yellow.

senses.sense: someone who watches an event, sport, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The stadium was packed with cheering spectators.
senses.lear_examp: At midnight sharp, fireworks covered the concert hall and I, as well as the rest of the spectators, felt the excitement and delight I've never felt before.

senses.sense: when people guess about something without having enough information to be certain
senses.dict_examp: She has dismissed the claims as pure speculation.
senses.lear_examp: I seriously urge your organization to base your reports on hard facts instead of speculation.

senses.sense: how fast something moves or happens
senses.dict_examp: high/low speed
senses.lear_examp: So we left at full speed!!!

senses.sense: very fast movement
senses.dict_examp: I get a real thrill from speed.
senses.lear_examp: Every summer I do watersports because I like water. I'm very good at swimming and I like the speed of some watersports.

senses.sense: having all the most recent information about a subject or activity
senses.dict_examp: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
senses.lear_examp: Apart from this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts.

senses.sense: to drive faster than you are allowed to according to the law
senses.dict_examp: She was exceeding the speed limit.
senses.lear_examp: There are three ground rules you have to follow: stop at stop signs, don't exceed the speed limit and don't be in the way of other cars.

senses.sense: forming words with the correct letters in the correct order, or the ability to do this
senses.dict_examp: Will I be marked wrong if I use British spellings rather than American?
senses.lear_examp: I want to ask my teacher to help me more with writing because I have a very bad problem with spelling and grammar.

senses.sense: a detailed description of how something should be done, made, etc.
senses.dict_examp: They are made exactly to the customer's specifications.
senses.lear_examp: Translating technical specifications prepared by non-native speakers can often cause serious problems.

senses.sense: an animal, plant, etc. used as an example of its type, especially for scientific study
senses.dict_examp: This is one of the museum's finest specimens.
senses.lear_examp: Plant life to is being given a hard time, as the would-be mountain explorers walk off the designated paths and wreak havoc in the wilderness, destroying many priceless specimens.

senses.sense: a special study area, work, skill, or product of a person, business, or place
senses.dict_examp: Her specialty is heart surgery.
senses.lear_examp: They provide courses the whole year round at all levels, although Business English is their specialty.

senses.sense: to write down or tell someone the correct letters that are used to make a word
senses.dict_examp: "How do you spell 'receive'?" "R E C E I V E."
senses.lear_examp: Then she made us spell our names.

senses.sense: for a particular reason, purpose, etc.
senses.dict_examp: They're designed specifically for children.
senses.lear_examp: I specifically chose to travel with you since your travel brochure promised a half-day trip to St. Andrews, where I was to meet my friend Ann.

senses.sense: exactly or in detail
senses.dict_examp: I specifically told them that she doesn't eat meat.
senses.lear_examp: More specifically, students have to complete numerous questions with very long answers for four different subjects, and the time available for each subject is three hours.

senses.sense: to spend most of your time studying one particular subject or doing one type of business
senses.dict_examp: She hired a lawyer who specializes in accident cases.
senses.lear_examp: I study economics and finance, specializing in insurance.

senses.sense: a group of plants or animals that share similar characteristics
senses.dict_examp: Mountain gorillas are an endangered species.
senses.lear_examp: Then I wrote an article about saving endangered species.

senses.sense: better or more important than usual things
senses.dict_examp: a special friend
senses.lear_examp: I got many presents from my friends, and I got a special present from my dad - it was a new bike

senses.sense: a price which is lower than usual
senses.dict_examp: There's a special offer on sunglasses  this week.
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, they have stopped their special offer "1 month for Euro 100" and I know that you want to stay fit. As soon as they make a new offer I will let you know and then you can join us!

senses.sense: different from normal things, or used for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: You need to use a special kind of paint.
senses.lear_examp: He stepped into a small, handmade, wooden canoe - it's called Hakaro. It's a special kind of canoe.

senses.sense: treatment that is better than usual
senses.dict_examp: I don't expect special treatment - I just want to be treated fairly.
senses.lear_examp: As you know, an Austin Healey needs special treatment.

senses.sense: the part of a radio, CD player, etc. which the sound comes out of
senses.dict_examp: I bought some new speakers for my CD player.
senses.lear_examp: I can give you 6, big, high quality speakers for the concert.

senses.sense: someone who can speak English/Spanish, etc.
senses.dict_examp: He's a fluent Russian speaker.
senses.lear_examp: I think I'm going to be an English speaker sooner than I expected.

senses.sense: someone who makes a speech to a group of people
senses.dict_examp: a good public speaker
senses.lear_examp: The speaker told me many things about feeding birds.

senses.sense: to state or describe something clearly and exactly
senses.dict_examp: He said we should meet but didn't specify a time.
senses.lear_examp: You did not specify what kind of work you are supposed to do either in a restaurant or in a museum.

senses.sense: to guess possible answers to a question when you do not have enough information to be certain
senses.dict_examp: The police refused to speculate about the cause of the accident.
senses.lear_examp: One can speculate endlessly without any inkling of what the subject involves and will never be able to be sure whether there is any truth behind their contemplations.

senses.sense: to use time doing something or being somewhere
senses.dict_examp: You need to spend at least 20 minutes on each exercise.
senses.lear_examp: We are going to spend the weekend in Paris.

senses.sense: to use money to buy or pay for something
senses.dict_examp: How much did you spend?
senses.lear_examp: I spent 500 dollars on this mobile phone.

senses.sense: for a particular purpose
senses.dict_examp: Her wheelchair was specially designed for her.
senses.lear_examp: I'm thinking of getting a beautiful long black wool coat specially made for you.

senses.sense: someone's ability to talk, or an example of someone talking
senses.dict_examp: People who suffer a stroke may experience a loss of speech.
senses.lear_examp: The reason why I decided to join the English class is because of my English speech, I should talk more fluently but I'm trying my best.

senses.sense: a formal talk given usually to a large number of people on a special occasion
senses.dict_examp: I had to give/make a speech at my brother's wedding.
senses.lear_examp: I suggest that if you want to invite someone to give a speech, you have to invite athletes.

senses.sense: the right to say or write what you want
senses.dict_examp: They fought for the right to free speech.
senses.lear_examp: Music, especially punk-music, symbolizes freedom of speech.

senses.sense: someone who has a lot of experience, knowledge, or skill in a particular subject
senses.dict_examp: a software specialist
senses.lear_examp: Now, fully equipped and powerful computers can be so small and mobile that some specialists predict that new devices will replace the book.

senses.sense: used to refer to a particular thing and not something general
senses.dict_examp: English for specific purposes
senses.lear_examp: We need to see animals, study them, and in some cases find out why specific types of animals can't live in the nature which we have spoiled.

senses.sense: exact or containing details
senses.dict_examp: Could you be more specific about the problem?
senses.lear_examp: To be more specific, our students discovered that the majority of your exhibits did not function at all.

senses.sense: with small amounts and scattered over a large area
senses.dict_examp: This whole area is very sparsely populated.
senses.lear_examp: A lot of these young people usually come from sparsely populated areas and want to move to a major city in order to be where things are happening.

senses.sense: unable to speak because you are so angry, shocked, surprised, etc.
senses.dict_examp: I couldn't believe what he was telling me - I was speechless.
senses.lear_examp: Last year, I had the opportunity to visit Chania again with my family and I was speechless when I understood that everything has undergone rapid change, because of tourism.

senses.sense: extremely good, exciting, or surprising
senses.dict_examp: a spectacular view
senses.lear_examp: It is located in a tall building and has a spectacular view.

senses.sense: to say something using your voice
senses.dict_examp: Would you mind speaking more slowly, please?
senses.lear_examp: I like speaking also because I speak to everybody.

senses.sense: to be able to talk in a language
senses.dict_examp: He speaks fluent French.
senses.lear_examp: I don't speak English properly.

senses.sense: to talk about something
senses.dict_examp: Ted will speak about careers in education.
senses.lear_examp: They filmed the teachers speaking about this event, and the beautiful paintings made by the students.

senses.sense: used to explain that you are talking about something in a general/personal, etc., way
senses.dict_examp: Well, generally speaking, it's quicker if you take the train.
senses.lear_examp: Generally speaking, the best way to keep fit is to live a healthy life.

senses.sense: to deliver a formal talk to a group of people about a particular subject
senses.dict_examp: She was invited to speak at a conference in Madrid.
senses.lear_examp: On behalf of all its members, I would like to invite you to speak at one of our meetings.

senses.sense: to express the feelings, opinions, etc., of another person or a group of people
senses.dict_examp: I've been chosen to speak on behalf of the whole class.
senses.lear_examp: I think I speak for many when I say that school wouldn't be what it is, if it were not for the great men and women who sacrifice so much of their time so that we students can stimulate our minds and learn more.

senses.sense: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
senses.dict_examp: I do have a blog, so yes, I am a writer, so to speak.
senses.lear_examp: Maintaining a good working relationship with your colleagues is one of the critical factors in keeping the company you work for afloat, so to speak.

senses.sense: If something speaks for itself, it is clear and needs no further explanation.
senses.dict_examp: The school's excellent record speaks for itself.
senses.lear_examp: On the one hand the economic success of sports events speaks for itself.

senses.sense: If something speaks volumes, it makes an opinion, characteristic, or situation very clear without the use of words.
senses.dict_examp: She said very little, but her face spoke volumes.
senses.lear_examp: Although there is always something a country is famous for, cooking is what speaks volumes of its inhabitants and the region.

senses.sense: to say exactly what you think without worrying if it will upset anyone
senses.dict_examp: She has very strong opinions and she's not afraid to speak her mind.
senses.lear_examp: His father is even more eccentric, speaks his mind and has no manners at all.

senses.sense: to not speak to someone because you have argued with them
senses.dict_examp: My brother and I aren't on speaking terms.
senses.lear_examp: Just imagine how many are those who hate their relatives or at least one of their relatives and aren't even on speaking terms with them or him.

senses.sense: to speak in a louder voice so that people can hear you
senses.dict_examp: Could you speak up? We can't hear at the back.
senses.lear_examp: First of all, I read it far too fast and in a voice that was hardly audible, and people started to shout that they couldn't hear me and that I should speak up; it was terrible!

senses.sense: a man who is chosen to speak officially for a group or organization
senses.dict_examp: He was the spokesman for their organization.
senses.lear_examp: Becoming spokesman or woman for a good cause will lead to more popularity of and more attention for the cause.

senses.sense: a vegetable with large, dark green leaves and a strong taste
senses.dict_examp: spinach lasagne/salad
senses.lear_examp: The embarrassing moment came when I saw the first dish: carrots with spinach!

senses.sense: relating to deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs
senses.dict_examp: Traditional ways of life fulfilled both economic and spiritual needs.
senses.lear_examp: I'd like to get in contact with the amazing spiritual life in India. There is no other country in the world with so many different religions and sects.

senses.sense: great beauty, or something that causes admiration and attention
senses.dict_examp: It took several years to restore the building to its original splendor.
senses.lear_examp: Then, when I came back, I would be able to show this ancient civilization to the world in all it's glory and splendor.

senses.sense: a small creature with eight long legs which catches insects in a web
senses.dict_examp: a spider's web
senses.lear_examp: She is afraid of spiders.

senses.sense: relating to sports
senses.dict_examp: sports equipment
senses.lear_examp: You should go there because in a big school there are more possibilities of making new friendships and you can choose from a wide range of sports activities.

senses.sense: a subject or area of knowledge, work, etc.
senses.dict_examp: the political sphere
senses.lear_examp: There is a very big crew, all of them very good in their sphere of work.

senses.sense: to divide into smaller parts or groups, or to divide something into smaller parts or groups
senses.dict_examp: The prize was split between Susan and Kate.
senses.lear_examp: In my opinion we might just split a full-time salary.

senses.sense: to share something by dividing it into smaller parts
senses.dict_examp: The cost of the wedding will be split between the two families.
senses.lear_examp: Sharing is cheaper since you always split the bills two or more ways and in your own place you cook your own food.

senses.sense: If something splits or if you split it, it comes apart so that there is a long, thin hole in it.
senses.dict_examp: His shorts split when he tried to jump the fence.
senses.lear_examp: It made a satisfying crashing noise as the frame and glass split.

senses.sense: If a group of people splits, or something splits them, they disagree and form smaller groups.
senses.dict_examp: This issue could split the Republican Party.
senses.lear_examp: This debate has affected a lot of discussions and split public opinion.

senses.sense: If two people who are married or have a relationship split up, they end it.
senses.dict_examp: They've split up.
senses.lear_examp: I asked her about the family and about her. She had recently split up with her boyfriend, Joe.

senses.sense: although something exists or happens
senses.dict_examp: He still smokes, in spite of all the health warnings.
senses.lear_examp: In spite of the bad weather, we went to the zoo and strolled around a lot.

senses.sense: a feeling of anger toward someone that makes you want to hurt or upset them
senses.dict_examp: He hid my new jacket out of spite.
senses.lear_examp: She did not do that out of spite or vengeance.

senses.sense: to pour liquid or another substance somewhere without intending to, or to fall or flow out of a container in  a way that is not intended
senses.dict_examp: I spilled coffee on my silk shirt.
senses.lear_examp: Then I'm going to buy a new rug, because a few days ago,  I spilled some juice.

senses.sense: a small, round mark which is a different color from the surface it is on
senses.dict_examp: He had a spot on his tie.
senses.lear_examp: This lamp is green with yellow spots on it and in my opinion it's perfect for my room.

senses.sense: a  place
senses.dict_examp: This looks like a nice spot for a picnic.
senses.lear_examp: Lake Frene is just a lake, there's nothing to do and it's a crowded spot.

senses.sense: to like someone or something a lot
senses.dict_examp: I've always had a soft spot for her.
senses.lear_examp: I would definitely like to return there because I really enjoy museums and as I have always had a soft spot for art, I can say that, that Foundation is my cup of tea.

senses.sense: immediately
senses.dict_examp: I accepted the job on the spot.
senses.lear_examp: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot.

senses.sense: to ask someone a question that is difficult or embarrassing to answer at that time
senses.dict_examp: Sorry to put you on the spot, but I really need an answer.

senses.sense: to see or notice something or someone
senses.dict_examp: I've just spotted Malcolm - he's over there, near the entrance.
senses.lear_examp: It is very easy to spot because there is a big sign for the hotel next to the building.

senses.sense: when someone gives money to support something
senses.dict_examp: We wanted to set up a youth center, and asked local businesses for sponsorship.
senses.lear_examp: The aim of this proposal is to explain the reason why our company can sponsor our country's tennis championship and outline the benefits we will gain from this sponsorship.

senses.sense: If something spins or you spin something, it turns around and around quickly.
senses.dict_examp: The car spun across the road.
senses.lear_examp: When the valve of the reservoir is opened, it passes through a pipe and it makes the turbine spin.

senses.sense: If you spin around, or someone spins you around, your body turns quickly to face the opposite direction.
senses.dict_examp: She spun around to see what had happened.
senses.lear_examp: She felt this pleasant drift immediately and spun around, being afraid that she would see someone at the doorway.

senses.sense: the long structure of bones down the center of your back, which supports your body
senses.dict_examp: She injured her spine in a riding accident.
senses.lear_examp: I use this center because my doctor recommended I follow a very specific type of exercise to correct problems that I have with my spine.

senses.sense: to make you feel afraid or excited
senses.dict_examp: The sound of his voice sent shivers down my spine.
senses.lear_examp: Simply looking at her sent shivers down his spine - there was the love of his life, the dearest woman on good old Earth, that he's never met before.

senses.sense: to give money to someone to support an activity, event, or organization, sometimes as a way to advertise your company or product
senses.dict_examp: The Rotary Club sponsors Little League baseball in the summer.
senses.lear_examp: The whole event is organized by university students and is sponsored by local firms.

senses.sense: a person or organization that gives money to support an activity, event, etc
senses.dict_examp: Corporate sponsors support many public TV programs.
senses.lear_examp: The party starts at 7:30 p.m and it is organized by Mr. Arm who is the sponsor of the conference.

senses.sense: to stop something from being enjoyable or successful
senses.dict_examp: He tried not to let the bad news spoil his evening.
senses.lear_examp: Nothing was able to spoil my holiday!

senses.sense: If you spoil a child, you let them have anything they want or do anything they want, usually making them badly behaved.
senses.dict_examp: Her children are completely spoiled.
senses.lear_examp: Are rich kids inevitably spoiled? Will all poor kids learn the value of a dollar? I believe that this is only a common yet fallacious stereotype.

senses.sense: containing spices that have strong flavor and are hot to the taste
senses.dict_examp: Do you like spicy food?
senses.lear_examp: I don't like spicy food, it's not good for my stomach.

senses.sense: the money which is used for a particular purpose, especially by a government or organization
senses.dict_examp: government spending on health care
senses.lear_examp: "If I become Prime Minister, the first issues on my political agenda will be to curb government spending on armaments, to reorganize the bureaucratic system, to reduce the rate of unemployment," he told me the last time I saw him.

senses.sense: stylish and suitable for people who are active
senses.dict_examp: a sporty new car

senses.sense: to force liquid out of your mouth
senses.dict_examp: I don't like to see people spitting in public.
senses.lear_examp: Eric could ride a horse like nobody else, he could spit the furthest and climb the highest trees, and one year Eric broke his leg and had to be taken to the hospital in an ambulance.

senses.sense: a situation which is getting worse very quickly, and which is difficult to control
senses.dict_examp: After his death, the family went into a downward spiral.
senses.lear_examp: Unemployment is one of the major problems of our society. It is the first step of a downward spiral.

senses.sense: a game or activity which people do to keep healthy or for enjoyment, often competing against each other
senses.dict_examp: Football, baseball, basketball, and hockey are all team sports.
senses.lear_examp: I don't like when I must play golf.  I don't like this sport.

senses.sense: an object with a handle and a round, curved part at one end, used for eating and serving food
senses.dict_examp: Could I have a spoon, please?
senses.lear_examp: Can I give you some knives and spoons for the cake?

senses.sense: someone who is chosen to speak officially for a group or organization
senses.dict_examp: She was the spokesperson for the group.
senses.lear_examp: As the local community spokesperson, my ability to plan, initiate and execute the cleaning of rivers, within our local community as a start, will be beneficial to the "Protect our river" requirements.

senses.sense: If a liquid splashes or you splash a liquid, drops of it hit or fall on something.
senses.dict_examp: Water was splashing from a hole in the roof.
senses.lear_examp: But in some towns we stayed in,  there were public swimming pools so we could even splash in the water.

senses.sense: to move in water so that drops of it go in all directions
senses.dict_examp: The children splashed through the puddles.
senses.lear_examp: So we were splashing around and then went to dry ourselves.

senses.sense: the sound of something falling into or moving in water
senses.dict_examp: They sat listening to the splash of raindrops on the lake.
senses.lear_examp: My friend, the mechanic Alex, heard a strange noise, a very powerful splash in the sea, and a lot of water came into the boat.

senses.sense: a drop of liquid that has fallen on something, or the mark made by it
senses.dict_examp: There were several small splashes of paint on the carpet.
senses.lear_examp: And at precisely 6pm, the sky is painted with a splash of orange and there you can enjoy one of the best sunsets in the world.

senses.sense: to get a lot of public attention
senses.dict_examp: The movie made quite a splash in the US.
senses.lear_examp: Moreover, it is no use splashing your money around on expensive gifts because this behavior shows that you are not happy but your purpose is to make a splash.

senses.sense: very good or very beautiful, special, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a splendid idea
senses.lear_examp: As far as interviewing sports personalities is concerned, it would be a splendid idea to interview Gerry Armstrong because he would be able to inform students about football, as he is a very good player.

senses.sense: in a way that relates to deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs
senses.dict_examp: We returned from our vacation refreshed both physically and spiritually.
senses.lear_examp: This view of life and work is not right, according to my beliefs, since being rich can lead to happiness, but may also lead you to poverty, spiritually speaking.

senses.sense: the way people think and feel about something
senses.dict_examp: The players have a very strong team spirit.
senses.lear_examp: In addition to that, you should invite athletes who have experience in sports to speak about team spirit and the role that sports have in our life.

senses.sense: feeling good/excited/unhappy, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The whole class was in good spirits that day.
senses.lear_examp: I was in high spirits until I got my paper back.

senses.sense: a form of a dead person such as a ghost
senses.dict_examp: an evil spirit
senses.lear_examp: I thought the house could have ghosts or spirits and because of this, I tried to convince myself that it had been my imagination, but suddenly the lights went out.

senses.sense: the part of a person which is not their body, which some people believe continues to exist after they die
senses.dict_examp: I believe my spirit will live on after I die.
senses.lear_examp: I would like to tell José San Martin that even if he could not reach his goal, without him, we would still be a dependent country. Furthermore, that his spirit was, is and will be in our hearts and minds.

senses.sense: a strong alcoholic drink, such as whisky or vodka
senses.dict_examp: I don't often drink spirits.
senses.lear_examp: There will be starters, meat, fish, desserts... and a lot of Rioja's wine, of course! Champagne and spirits too.

senses.sense: a substance made from a plant, which is used to give a special taste to food
senses.dict_examp: Cinnamon, ginger and cloves are all spices.
senses.lear_examp: It's very delicious with some spices and many kinds of salad.

senses.sense: something that makes something else more exciting
senses.dict_examp: A scandal or two adds a little spice to office life.
senses.lear_examp: Yes, we just have to believe in ourselves, add a little spice to our days and face the world - no matter which world.

senses.sense: to gradually affect a larger area
senses.dict_examp: The fire spread very rapidly because of the strong wind.
senses.lear_examp: It seemed that the fire might spread more.

senses.sense: If information spreads, or if someone spreads it, it is communicated to many people.
senses.dict_examp: News of his victory spread quickly.
senses.lear_examp: The news spread all over the village.

senses.sense: to cover an area
senses.dict_examp: The suburbs spread for miles in every direction.
senses.lear_examp: It has about 500 inhabitants, who live in 128 houses, which are spread over a big area.

senses.sense: to arrange something over a large area, especially something that was folded
senses.dict_examp: I spread a blanket over his legs.
senses.lear_examp: She looked at all the diaries that were all spread out around her on the bed.

senses.sense: to move a soft substance across a surface so that it covers it
senses.dict_examp: What I really like is hot, buttered toast spread  with strawberry jam.
senses.lear_examp: The British are astonished when they see Catalans rubbing their bread with ripe tomatoes. Likewise Spaniards feel surprised when Europeans spread butter on it instead.

senses.sense: to arrange for something to happen over a period of time and not at once
senses.dict_examp: The payments will be spread over two years.
senses.lear_examp: This would both spread the cost and make the whole plan more workable.

senses.sense: If people spread out, they move from being close together in a group to being in different places across a larger area.
senses.dict_examp: They spread out to search the whole area.
senses.lear_examp: They don't dare to spread out in the space.

senses.sense: when something moves to cover a larger area or affect a larger number of people

senses.sense: liquid in a container which forces it out in small drops

senses.sense: to force liquid out of a container in many small drops

senses.sense: not likely to change, become worse, or end suddenly

senses.sense: mentally calm and not easily upset

senses.sense: a small, round mark which is a different color from the surface it is on

senses.sense: a  place

senses.sense: to like someone or something a lot

senses.sense: immediately
senses.dict_examp: I accepted the job on the spot.

senses.sense: to ask someone a question that is difficult or embarrassing to answer at that time

senses.sense: to see or notice something or someone

senses.lear_examp: It is very easy to spot because there is a big sign for the hotel next to the building.

senses.sense: making short, high sounds

senses.sense: to waste time, money, etc.

senses.sense: a shape with four equal sides and four 90° angles

senses.sense: an open area with buildings around it in a city or town

senses.sense: your husband or wife

senses.sense: the season of the year between winter and summer, when the weather becomes warmer and plants start to grow again

senses.sense: a place where water comes out of the ground

senses.sense: to appear suddenly

senses.sense: when someone gets public attention by being on television, in the newspapers, etc.

senses.sense: completely clean

senses.sense: to push a knife into someone

senses.sense: a group of police officers who have special skills to deal with particular problems

senses.sense: a sports team

senses.lear_examp: The town has a wonderful zoo with a lot of animals and a great stadium for soccer games.

senses.sense: used with "not" to say you will not accept a situation or a particular type of behavior

senses.dict_examp: He stands to gain a fortune if the company is sold.
senses.lear_examp: International tourism should be encouraged, rather than reduced, because countries that are still developing stand to gain a lot from visitors from other parts of the world.

senses.sense: what someone thinks about you, how they expect you to behave, and how they are likely to behave
senses.dict_examp: He didn’t even send me a birthday card, so I guess I know where I stand.

senses.sense: what your opinion is about something
senses.dict_examp: The Senator has made it clear where she stands on these issues.
senses.lear_examp: From where I stand, some action must be taken urgently because the problems are constantly exacerbating.

senses.sense: to have a chance of success or of achieving something
senses.dict_examp: He doesn’t stand much of a chance in the election.
senses.lear_examp: If this measure were taken, the outcome would be of fundamental importance for the currently unemployed because they will stand a chance of finding a job and making a living.

senses.sense: as something is now, without changes in it
senses.dict_examp: The law as it stands is very unclear.
senses.lear_examp: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure.

senses.sense: to refuse to change your opinion or give in to an argument
senses.dict_examp: I kept trying to get my grandmother to find  a smaller house, but she stood her ground.
senses.lear_examp: She said she would stand her ground, and never, never falter.

senses.sense: If you will not stand for something, you will not accept a situation or a particular type of behavior
senses.dict_examp: I wouldn't stand for that sort of behavior from him, if I were you.
senses.lear_examp: Much as I admire the performance of the new aircraft today, I understand your need to fly and test new technologies, but I will not stand for it any longer.

senses.sense: to move a short distance away from something or someone
senses.dict_examp: Please stand back - then all of you will be able to see what I'm doing.

senses.sense: to support or be loyal to someone
senses.dict_examp: The boy’s friends stood by him, firmly convinced of his innocence.
senses.lear_examp: And I promise I'll stand by you.

senses.sense: to support or represent a particular idea or set of ideas
senses.dict_examp: This party stands for low taxes and individual freedom.
senses.lear_examp: She said she would stand her ground, and never, never stagger.

senses.sense: If one or more letters stand for a word or name, they are the first letter or letters of that word or name and they represent it
senses.dict_examp: "GMT" stands for Greenwich Mean Time.

senses.sense: used with "not" to say you will not accept a situation or a particular type of behavior
senses.dict_examp: Maybe you think his behavior is OK, but I won’t stand for it.
senses.lear_examp: Much as I admire the performance of the new aircraft today, I understand your need to fly and test new technologies, but I will not stand for it any longer.

senses.sense: to do something that someone else was going to do because they cannot be there
senses.dict_examp: She stood in for me when I was sick.
senses.lear_examp: As I will be away these two days, I have asked Mr. Ryman's secretary Sandy, to stand in for me.

senses.sense: to be much better than other similar things or people
senses.dict_examp: One candidate stood out from the rest.
senses.lear_examp: Those small fishing villages will always stand out in my memory.

senses.sense: to be easy to see or notice
senses.dict_examp: The bright blue letters really stand out on the page.
senses.lear_examp: Why wasn't that money spent in trying to make them more bearable to look at, rather than making them stand out even more?

senses.sense: to fail to meet someone you have arranged to see
senses.dict_examp: I was starting to think I'd been stood up when he finally arrived.

senses.sense: to defend or support a particular idea or a person who is being criticized or attacked
senses.dict_examp: It's high time we all stood up for our rights around here.
senses.lear_examp: He decides to stand up for black rights and becomes an important leader.

senses.sense: to defend yourself against a powerful person or organization when they treat you unfairly
senses.dict_examp: He wasn't afraid to stand up to bullies.
senses.lear_examp: They say that the best things in life are for free, courage, hope, love for freedom and the power to stand up to others, defending one's own rights.

senses.sense: a table or small structure from which goods are sold or shown
senses.dict_examp: a hot dog stand
senses.lear_examp: What I aimed for was to get in touch with as many interesting companies as I could, and I really did it because there were lots of stands with a good choice of companies, ranging fro the biggest ones (IBB or Siemens, for example) to other smaller but also interesting.

senses.sense: to publicly defend something or stop something from happening
senses.dict_examp: It's about time someone made a stand.
senses.lear_examp: We cannot simply stand by while our greenery is being destroyed, so I am making a stand.

senses.sense: a piece of furniture for holding things
senses.dict_examp: a music/hat stand
senses.lear_examp: We go backstage, the audience is still clapping and the people in the orchestra are beating with their bows on the music stands.

senses.sense: to become ill or die because you do not have enough food, or to make someone ill or die because they do not have enough food
senses.dict_examp: Many people have starved to death in parts of Africa.
senses.lear_examp: People were starving to death and various crimes took place.

senses.sense: a building where trains or buses stop so that you can get on or off them
senses.dict_examp: a train/bus station
senses.lear_examp: I will meet you at the bus station.

senses.sense: a company that broadcasts television or radio programs
senses.dict_examp: a radio/television station
senses.lear_examp: Last week I was listening to my favorite radio station and they announced a new sports club.

senses.sense: using the newest ideas, designs, and materials
senses.dict_examp: It is a computer system that uses state-of-the-art technology.
senses.lear_examp: It is the impressive and simply state-of-the-art graphics that entice the player to spend hours in front of the screen.

senses.sense: an accepted or official position, especially in a social group
senses.dict_examp: The association works to promote the status of retired people as useful members of the community.
senses.lear_examp: Their status and income were shadowed by the state.

senses.sense: a level of quality, especially a level that is acceptable
senses.dict_examp: safety standards
senses.lear_examp: In conclusion, I hope that my ideas will help to improve the standards of this café and will bring more customers in the future.

senses.sense: how much money and comfort someone has
senses.dict_examp: a low/high standard of living
senses.lear_examp: I think we would have a better standard of living if we had this situation.

senses.sense: a level of behavior, especially a level that is acceptable
senses.dict_examp: high moral standards
senses.lear_examp: According to my moral standards, adults should not take advantage of children's lack of experience and they should certainly not incite them to tell lies and betray others.

senses.sense: usual rather than special, especially when thought of as being correct or acceptable
senses.dict_examp: a standard contract
senses.lear_examp: It should be a standard price.

senses.sense: to begin doing something
senses.dict_examp: When do you start your English course/your new job?
senses.lear_examp: Dear Ramesh, I start my class at 9:30 am.

senses.sense: to begin to happen or to make something begin to happen
senses.dict_examp: His mother started the craft market at the community center.
senses.lear_examp: After that we started a discussion about social life.

senses.sense: If a business or other organization starts, or if someone starts one, it is created and starts to operate.
senses.dict_examp: She started her own software company.
senses.lear_examp: It was the first time in many years he had the opportunity or time to think over his situation and life. He had started his company fifteen years ago and had been successful.

senses.sense: If you start a machine or an engine, you switch it on, and if a machine or engine starts, it begins to work.
senses.dict_examp: The car wouldn't start.
senses.lear_examp: The car would not start and it was impossible to get a taxi because it was Saturday evening, so the only thing we could do was to run all the way to the school.

senses.sense: used before saying the first thing in a list of things
senses.dict_examp: To start with, we need better computers. Then we need more training.
senses.lear_examp: There is some information I should tell you about. To start with, the T.V. repairman didn't come on Wednesday morning as expected.

senses.sense: to begin by doing something, or to make something begin by doing something
senses.dict_examp: She started off the meeting with the monthly sales report.
senses.lear_examp: We started off the trip by driving to the foot of the mountain, where there was a village.

senses.sense: to begin your life, or the part of your life when you work, in a particular way
senses.dict_examp: My dad started out as a sales assistant in a department store.
senses.lear_examp: She is a beautiful, talented woman who started out as a small actress in her own country, climbing up to become the fully-recognized celebrity that she is now.

senses.sense: the beginning of something
senses.dict_examp: We were doubtful from the start.
senses.lear_examp: My first experience was a good start, I could understand everything that the teacher said and I was also able to communicate with the other students, of course there are still mistakes which I will try to improve.

senses.sense: an advantage that you have over someone else when you begin something
senses.dict_examp: I'm grateful for the start I had in life.
senses.lear_examp: With a better start in life these children will be less likely to end up on the street again.

senses.sense: to remain in a place, job, etc. and not leave
senses.dict_examp: I have a meeting at three so I can’t stay long.
senses.lear_examp: During the break times, I prefer to stay in the classroom just to read the French-English dictionary, so I learn or discover many other words that I can use in my speech.

senses.sense: to live or be in a place for a short time as a visitor
senses.dict_examp: I stayed in Montreal for two weeks then flew home.
senses.lear_examp: Last week I went to visit Egypt for 10 days.  I stayed in Cairo 5 days.  It's a good town but it's very busy.

senses.sense: to continue to be in a particular state
senses.dict_examp: The supermarket stays open late.
senses.lear_examp: Some people prefer to stay dry rather than be caught by the rain.

senses.sense: to remain in the same place and not leave there
senses.dict_examp: He told me to stay put while he went to get the car.
senses.lear_examp: It was extremely stressful and she didn't like the working conditions and atmosphere at work, but as it was difficult to find another job, she stayed put.

senses.sense: to remain away from something or to avoid something
senses.dict_examp: Stay away from the edge of the cliff.
senses.lear_examp: The place is small and with a lot of trees if you prefer to stay away from the hot summer sun or if you feel like having a picnic.

senses.sense: to remain at a place when other people leave it
senses.dict_examp: Francine went on ahead and I stayed behind to wait for Annie.
senses.lear_examp: The tourists were to stay behind, waiting for his return, so they all made themselves comfortable as well as they could.

senses.sense: to remain somewhere for a longer time than expected or after other people have left
senses.dict_examp: His boss asked him to stay on as manager for another year.
senses.lear_examp: Thus it can be seen in the novel that Olivia left her husband for another man and that she was determined to stay on in India in spite of her friends judging her.

senses.sense: to not come home at night, or to go home late
senses.dict_examp: My folks don't let me stay out late.
senses.lear_examp: Firstly, I like it so much because we have no school and we can stay out for as long as we want.

senses.sense: to not become involved in an argument or discussion
senses.dict_examp: It's better to stay out of their arguments.

senses.sense: to spend the night somewhere instead of returning to your home or continuing your journey
senses.dict_examp: Why don't you stay over and drive back in the morning?
senses.lear_examp: We stayed over in a hotel and the next morning Tom brought me home.

senses.sense: to go to bed later than usual
senses.dict_examp: We stayed up (late) to watch a movie on TV.
senses.lear_examp: In Vegas, we were staying up all night gambling.

senses.sense: a period of time that you spend in a place
senses.dict_examp: Did you enjoy your stay in Tokyo?
senses.lear_examp: I hope my stay in London will be an interesting experience, because I paid a lot for this trip.

senses.sense: ill or dying because there is not enough food
senses.dict_examp: starving people
senses.lear_examp: What shocked me most was the misery and poverty: thousands of homeless people roaming the streets starving and cold.

senses.sense: very hungry
senses.dict_examp: I'm absolutely starving.
senses.lear_examp: I've always been greedy, but at that moment, while my Chemistry teacher was explaining a difficult lesson, I was really starving.

senses.sense: a collection of facts in the form of numbers that show information about something
senses.dict_examp: The statistics show that, in general, women live longer than men.
senses.lear_examp: According to statistics based on the questionnaire, the majority of students feel the most enthusiasm for their English class.

senses.sense: a famous singer, actor, sports person, etc.
senses.dict_examp: a rock/movie/basketball star
senses.lear_examp: I really liked it because lots of soccer stars were there and both teams played very well, but Brazil won, of course.

senses.sense: a ball of burning gases that you see as a small point of light in the sky at night
senses.dict_examp: Stars twinkled/shone in the night sky.
senses.lear_examp: Well, it's really big, with two windows to see the garden in the morning, and the stars at night.

senses.sense: a shape or symbol with four or more points
senses.dict_examp: star-shaped
senses.lear_examp: It has pink flowers and blue stars.

senses.sense: used to show how good a restaurant or hotel is
senses.dict_examp: a five-star hotel
senses.lear_examp: Also the facilities were great and people started building houses, and the small village became an attractive town with museums, universities, wonderful beaches, five-star hotels and other beautiful facilities.

senses.sense: someone or something that is better than all the others in a group
senses.dict_examp: He is one of our star players.
senses.lear_examp: He led Brazil to win two more World Cups, and in both of them he was the star player, the black prince.

senses.sense: If a film, play, etc. stars someone, or if someone stars in a film, play, etc., they are the main actor in it.
senses.dict_examp: Ben Kingsley starred in the film "Gandhi."
senses.lear_examp: As we both love romantic comedy, we decided to see  Notting Hill together, which starred Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant.

senses.sense: a part of a large country with its own government, such as in Brazil, Mexico, or the US
senses.dict_examp: Alaska is the largest state in the US.
senses.lear_examp: If you have time, you will enjoy walking in the mountains at Miras Gerais, which is an important Brazilian state. The sunset there is wonderful.

senses.sense: the condition that something or someone is in
senses.dict_examp: The building is in a terrible state.
senses.lear_examp: Some people say TV can be harmful because it keeps our mind in a passive state.

senses.sense: a country or its government
senses.dict_examp: The drought is worst in the central African states.
senses.lear_examp: I opted, since I must talk about my country's history, to choose an event not from the whole history of the Greek nation, but from that of the independent Greek state (kingdom or republic, it depends on the period), which had a life of about 270-280 years.

senses.sense: to officially say or write something
senses.dict_examp: Our warranty clearly states the limits of our liability.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Mr Thomas, I've read your advertisement in the last issue of "The Traveller", where you state that you are looking for people to work on your campsites with English-speaking tourists.

senses.sense: provided, created, or done by a state in a country, or by the government of a country
senses.dict_examp: a state government/legislature/law
senses.lear_examp: Here in Argentina the rules at school depend on the school.  In general, the rules at private schools are much stricter than the ones at state schools.

senses.sense: relating to statistics
senses.dict_examp: There is no statistical evidence to support his claims.
senses.lear_examp: I just wondered why your newspaper didn't stick to the statistical figures and the pie chart we announced on the next day after the fund-raising activity.

senses.sense: a particular way of thinking about a situation or problem
senses.dict_examp: to look at something from a political/religious standpoint
senses.lear_examp: From a moral standpoint it can be argued that the income distribution that comes from such incredible payments is unacceptable.

senses.sense: something that people want to have because they think it will make people admire them
senses.dict_examp: For him, a big car is an important status symbol.
senses.lear_examp: Jobs now play a very important role as status symbols.

senses.sense: a model that looks like a person or animal, usually made from stone or metal
senses.dict_examp: a statue of a boy
senses.lear_examp: After, we passed in front of the statue of the president.

senses.sense: to look at someone or something for a long time and not move your eyes
senses.dict_examp: Don't stare at people like that, it's rude.
senses.lear_examp: David had seen her once before in a park, staring at him.

senses.sense: a very strong metal made from iron, used for making knives, machines, etc.
senses.dict_examp: steel pipes
senses.lear_examp: The object that I would choose is without any doubt my Katana, my Japanese Sword. It is a weapon that reminds me of my childhood games. I also like the form, and the cool steel of the blade.

senses.sense: hard and difficult to bend
senses.dict_examp: I need a stiff piece of cardboard.

senses.sense: not easy to move
senses.dict_examp: a stiff neck
senses.lear_examp: She tried to sit up straight and quickly realized all her muscles were stiff from non-activity.

senses.sense: behaving in a way that is formal and not relaxed
senses.dict_examp: He was always very stiff with us.
senses.lear_examp: In spite of his often stiff attitude, Mr. Stevens' very detailed description of their contact in the past and his eagerness to visit Miss Kenton in 1956 show that he does have strong feelings for her, even though he still hides this behind the eternal argument of "a need for contact of a purely professional character."

senses.sense: a strong alcoholic drink
senses.dict_examp: I thought he could use a stiff drink after that car almost hit him.
senses.lear_examp: Then, she prepared herself a stiff drink: gin and tonic with some ice, the very same one she used to have when Jack was there.

senses.sense: very severe or difficult
senses.dict_examp: stiff competition/opposition
senses.lear_examp: Furthermore, these budget airlines have given stiff competition to bigger airlines by reducing airfares.

senses.sense: extremely bored/scared/worried, etc.
senses.dict_examp: I pretended to listen, but I was bored stiff.
senses.lear_examp: Squeaky noises coming out from the deep corners of my house frightened me. I was scared stiff.

senses.sense: to control the direction of a vehicle
senses.dict_examp: She carefully steered the car around the potholes.
senses.lear_examp: After an hour she could keep her balance but she still had problems steering, but that didn't matter.

senses.sense: to avoid someone or something because they are unpleasant or dangerous
senses.dict_examp: Steer clear of Tony this morning - he's in a bad mood.
senses.lear_examp: Eating healthy doesn't mean starving, eating plants or steering clear of meat.

senses.sense: at a gradual, regular rate
senses.dict_examp: Prices have risen steadily over the last two decades.
senses.lear_examp: Towns are growing steadily and as a result of this animals disappear because we destroy forests, lakes, etc.

senses.sense: to remain in a place, job, etc. and not leave
senses.dict_examp: I have a meeting at three so I can’t stay long.
senses.lear_examp: During the break times, I prefer to stay in the classroom just to read the French-English dictionary, so I learn or discover many other words that I can use in my speech.

senses.sense: to live or be in a place for a short time as a visitor
senses.dict_examp: I stayed in Montreal for two weeks then flew home.
senses.lear_examp: Last week I went to visit Egypt for 10 days.  I stayed in Cairo 5 days.  It's a good town but it's very busy.

senses.sense: to continue to be in a particular state
senses.dict_examp: The supermarket stays open late.
senses.lear_examp: Some people prefer to stay dry rather than be caught by the rain.

senses.sense: to remain in the same place and not leave there
senses.dict_examp: He told me to stay put while he went to get the car.
senses.lear_examp: It was extremely stressful and she didn't like the working conditions and atmosphere at work, but as it was difficult to find another job, she stayed put.

senses.sense: to remain away from something or to avoid something
senses.dict_examp: Stay away from the edge of the cliff.
senses.lear_examp: The place is small and with a lot of trees if you prefer to stay away from the hot summer sun or if you feel like having a picnic.

senses.sense: to remain at a place when other people leave it
senses.dict_examp: Francine went on ahead and I stayed behind to wait for Annie.
senses.lear_examp: The tourists were to stay behind, waiting for his return, so they all made themselves comfortable as well as they could.

senses.sense: to remain somewhere for a longer time than expected or after other people have left
senses.dict_examp: His boss asked him to stay on as manager for another year.
senses.lear_examp: Thus it can be seen in the novel that Olivia left her husband for another man and that she was determined to stay on in India in spite of her friends judging her.

senses.sense: to not come home at night, or to go home late
senses.dict_examp: My folks don't let me stay out late.
senses.lear_examp: Firstly, I like it so much because we have no school and we can stay out for as long as we want.

senses.sense: to not become involved in an argument or discussion
senses.dict_examp: It's better to stay out of their arguments.

senses.sense: to spend the night somewhere instead of returning to your home or continuing your journey
senses.dict_examp: Why don't you stay over and drive back in the morning?
senses.lear_examp: We stayed over in a hotel and the next morning Tom brought me home.

senses.sense: to go to bed later than usual
senses.dict_examp: We stayed up (late) to watch a movie on TV.
senses.lear_examp: In Vegas, we were staying up all night gambling.

senses.sense: a period of time that you spend in a place
senses.dict_examp: Did you enjoy your stay in Tokyo?
senses.lear_examp: I hope my stay in London will be an interesting experience, because I paid a lot for this trip.

senses.sense: A steep slope, hill, etc. rises up high in a sudden, quick way.
senses.dict_examp: a steep slope
senses.lear_examp: But the slope was terribly steep and I didn't dare to ski down.

senses.sense: A steep increase or fall in something is very big and quick.
senses.dict_examp: There has been a steep increase/rise in prices.
senses.lear_examp: Company A starts the year 1990 with a profit figure of five million dollars, there is a steep rise, and profits reach to up to ten million dollars by year 1995.

senses.sense: to secretly take something that does not belong to you, without intending to return it
senses.dict_examp: She admitted stealing the money from her employers.
senses.lear_examp: All my friends gave me lots of presents, but I like the bike best. I like it because my bike was stolen.

senses.sense: a wheel that you turn to control the direction of a vehicle
senses.dict_examp: He took both hands off the steering wheel.
senses.lear_examp: After leaving your house on Monday morning, I gripped the steering wheel, fixed my eyes firmly on the road, and bravely drove my way up to Scotland.

senses.sense: to develop as the result of something
senses.dict_examp: Her problems stem from childhood.
senses.lear_examp: This educational approach stems from strong family values and religious beliefs.

senses.sense: one of the movements you make with your feet when you walk
senses.dict_examp: Sophie took her first steps when she was eleven months old.
senses.lear_examp: I tried to run but with my first step, I kicked something that fell to the floor.

senses.sense: one of the surfaces that you walk on when you go up or down stairs
senses.dict_examp: Mom took a picture of us sitting on the front steps of the house.
senses.lear_examp: I go down four steps and I am on the beach!

senses.sense: one of the things that you do to achieve something
senses.dict_examp: What's the next step in the instructions?
senses.lear_examp: We'd like to know how it feels to be in the film business, how you started and the steps you've taken to be where you are now.

senses.sense: moving slowly from one stage of something to the next
senses.dict_examp: I know there's a lot to prepare, but just take things step by step and don't worry.
senses.lear_examp: The book actually guides you step by step on how you can cope with this fear and defeat it.

senses.sense: to go back somewhere the same way that you came
senses.dict_examp: I was lost so I retraced my steps.
senses.lear_examp: Mentally retracing his steps of the morning, he remembered rushing out of his place at the last minute.

senses.sense: to move somewhere by lifting your foot and putting it down in a different place
senses.dict_examp: She stepped carefully over the dog.
senses.lear_examp: The moment he stepped out of the train he realized he had left his suitcase inside.

senses.sense: to put your foot on or in something
senses.dict_examp: I accidentally stepped on her foot.
senses.lear_examp: I had to dance with a boy whose name is Alex and every time he stepped on my feet.

senses.sense: to leave an important job
senses.dict_examp: She stepped down as captain of the swim team.
senses.lear_examp: Thus, he decided to retire, to step down from the tough and competitive environment and planned for the rest of his life.

senses.sense: to become joined to something else or to make something become joined to something else, usually with a substance like glue
senses.dict_examp: Stick the tape on the back of the picture.
senses.lear_examp: Then I am going to buy those glow-in-the-dark stars to stick on the ceiling, so that at night, I can see stars.

senses.sense: If something sharp sticks into something, it goes into it, and if you stick something sharp somewhere, you push it into something.
senses.dict_examp: The nurse stuck the needle into his arm.
senses.lear_examp: The body of his boss's wife lay on the ground, a knife stuck in her heart.

senses.sense: to continue to support someone when they are having problems
senses.dict_examp: I'll stick by you whatever happens.

senses.sense: to go past the surface or edge of something
senses.dict_examp: Ryan's ears stick out a little, don't they!
senses.lear_examp: The seat was damaged and something was sticking out.

senses.sense: to limit yourself to doing or using one particular thing and not change to anything else
senses.dict_examp: Could you stick to the point, please?
senses.lear_examp: I'll stick to baggy t-shirts, jeans, baseball caps and sneakers.

senses.sense: If people stick together, they support and help each other.
senses.dict_examp: If we all stick together, we can succeed.
senses.lear_examp: Who would ever have thought that the little school band from the good old days would get so far? It must be at least 20 years since we left school, and I haven't seen any of the good old school mates for more than 10 years, but they must have stuck together.

senses.sense: to support someone or something when they are being criticized
senses.dict_examp: I feel I have to stick up for him.
senses.lear_examp: Two brothers Lev and Dmitri used to stick up for each other at school and could never be beaten at any physical sport because they were extremely strong.

senses.sense: to continue doing something or using someone to do work for you, and not stopping or changing to something or someone else

senses.sense: when you say one part of a word more strongly than the rest
senses.dict_examp: The meaning of a sentence often depends on stress and intonation.

senses.sense: to emphasize something in order to show that it is important
