senses.dict_examp: Fran supplied the sandwiches for the party.
senses.lear_examp: I would be able to supply you with a reference from my employer.

senses.sense: having the highest rank or the most importance or at the highest level
senses.dict_examp: the Supreme Court
senses.lear_examp: I would go back to the time when emperors reigned supreme in China and the West had not yet discovered it.

senses.sense: certain
senses.dict_examp: "What's wrong with him?" "I'm not sure."
senses.lear_examp: I think it's in your room but I'm not sure.

senses.sense: to take action so that you are certain that something happens, is true, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Make sure that the door is locked.
senses.lear_examp: So please make sure that you wear old clothes.

senses.sense: without any doubt
senses.dict_examp: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
senses.lear_examp: For sure, you'll love Brazil.

senses.sense: to be confident of your own abilities, qualities, etc.
senses.dict_examp: She seems a bit more sure of herself since she got a job.
senses.lear_examp: He is a tall, dark man who walks with confidence and is sure of himself because of his success in the world of business.

senses.sense: to be confident that something is true
senses.dict_examp: He'll win this year, I'm sure of it.
senses.lear_examp: I think that I would be a really useful person for your company. I'm sure of it.

senses.sense: something that is certain to happen
senses.dict_examp: Your promotion is a sure thing – you’re the best person for the job.
senses.lear_examp: Although I never knew at which time it would be, the only sure thing I had in mind was the need to come back home, into your arms!

senses.sense: If you are sure to do something, it is certain that you will do it.
senses.dict_examp: He's sure to go back there again.
senses.lear_examp: What she does not know is that her ex-husband has a very serious type of cancer and is sure to pass away in a few months (that is why he agrees to spend his summer with his son, knowing it would be the last).

senses.sense: as expected
senses.dict_examp: He said the book was on his desk, and sure enough, there it was.
senses.lear_examp: And sure enough, these challenging problems come unsolicited most of the time.

senses.sense: used to show agreement
senses.dict_examp: "Can I take this pen?" "Sure."
senses.lear_examp: Sure! I want to go with you.

senses.sense: used to show that you are not certain about something
senses.dict_examp: It was sort of interesting, I suppose.
senses.lear_examp: I'll travel by taxi and I don't know how long I'll stay there, two or three days, I suppose.

senses.sense: used to show agreement to something when you do not really want to
senses.dict_examp: I suppose you're right.

senses.sense: to be expected or intended to do something, especially when this does not happen
senses.dict_examp: The medication is supposed to reduce pain.
senses.lear_examp: I'm supposed to go cycling with some friends of mine to Bondi.

senses.sense: to be expected to be something, especially because of a rule, agreement, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The children are supposed to be at school by 8:45 a.m.
senses.lear_examp: It was supposed to be a surprise... I had been in London for a long time.

senses.sense: to be considered by many people to be something
senses.dict_examp: The scenery is supposed to be fantastic.
senses.lear_examp: I knew that he had booked a table for two in one of the most expensive restaurants in town, where the food was supposed to be excellent.

senses.sense: If you are supposed to do something, the rules say that you should do it.
senses.dict_examp: You're supposed to pay by the end of the month.
senses.lear_examp: Unfortunately, the organizer came to me and let me know that I was not supposed to sell anything in that area.

senses.sense: to think that something is likely to be true
senses.dict_examp: He found it a lot more difficult to get a job than he supposed it would be.
senses.lear_examp: It is supposed that this man could have also been a chemist, as writings have been found and recovered with clues to what Da Vinci might have been doing in that field.

senses.sense: used to introduce an idea for someone to consider
senses.dict_examp: Suppose he phones tonight. What should I say?
senses.lear_examp: Suppose one company wants to have a party to promote new products.

senses.sense: a large store that sells many different foods and other products used in the home
senses.dict_examp: I have to stop at the supermarket on the way home.
senses.lear_examp: The supermarket is on Church Street near the post office.

senses.sense: used to show that you believe something is very likely
senses.dict_examp: Surely they'd have called us by now to say they're not coming.
senses.lear_examp: Surely the trip with your parents will be very nice.

senses.sense: used to express surprise that something has happened or is going to happen
senses.dict_examp: Surely you don't expect me to believe that?
senses.lear_examp: Surely it doesn't mean that they have learned the exciting news?

senses.sense: when you supervise someone or something
senses.dict_examp: He needs constant supervision.
senses.lear_examp: The little one was built especially for you, so that you can leave your children under the supervision of two well-trained lifeguards.

senses.sense: an extra amount or part added to something
senses.dict_examp: to take a vitamin                       supplement
senses.lear_examp: No miracle promises for overnight improvements, no food supplement and pills will bring the desired results.

senses.sense: to add to something to make it larger or better
senses.dict_examp: He supplements his income by working in a bar in the evenings.
senses.lear_examp: He was moonlighting to supplement his income.

senses.sense: a person whose job is to supervise someone or something
senses.dict_examp: His supervisor told him to work faster.
senses.lear_examp: I held the post of general supervisor in a campus in Oxford two years ago, and now I am working as a receptionist in a luxurious hotel.

senses.sense: used to show that you do not believe that something you have been told is true
senses.dict_examp: Well, the tickets are supposedly in the mail.
senses.lear_examp: "The Bride" sets out to kill the first of Bill's assassins, supposedly the most dangerous person in the world in terms of knives.

senses.sense: used to describe things that cannot be explained by our knowledge of science or nature
senses.dict_examp: supernatural powers/forces
senses.lear_examp: The book consists of six completely different 'ghost stories' which involve ghosts and supernatural phenomena, something that attracts young readers.

senses.sense: things that cannot be explained by our knowledge of science or nature
senses.dict_examp: She's very interested in the supernatural.

senses.sense: the form of an adjective or adverb which expresses that the thing or person being described has more of the particular quality than anything or anyone else of the same type
senses.dict_examp: "Richest" is the superlative of "rich."

senses.sense: to watch a person or activity to make certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
senses.dict_examp: The UN is supervising the distribution of aid by local agencies in the disaster area.
senses.lear_examp: Our main activity will be to supervise the 8 to 12 year olds during those activities.

senses.sense: someone who supports a particular idea, group or person
senses.dict_examp: Supporters of the bill expect it to pass.
senses.lear_examp: According to supporters of Animal Rights, people wouldn't like being kept in zoos.

senses.sense: to look after someone by paying for their food, clothes, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Both parents work full time to support their family.
senses.lear_examp: Sara has to work hard to support her family.

senses.sense: to help someone, often when they are having problems
senses.dict_examp: My family has always supported me in whatever I've wanted to do.
senses.lear_examp: You can meet a lot of people who can support you in your research, and have a lot of friends too, and large schools have better facilities.

senses.sense: to like a particular sports team, often going to see them play
senses.dict_examp: I'm not a Mets fan - I've always supported the Yankees.
senses.lear_examp: I liked it very much because this is the team that I support.

senses.sense: to agree with an idea, group, or person
senses.dict_examp: Do you support their views on the environment?
senses.lear_examp: I support this idea because I believe that it is the only way to stop the traffic in cities.

senses.sense: to give encouragement or financial help to someone or something because you want them to succeed
senses.dict_examp: I think it's important to support local businesses by buying locally.
senses.lear_examp: These films are more attractive for older viewers and support the local film business.

senses.sense: to help to show that something is true
senses.dict_examp: There's no evidence to support his story.
senses.lear_examp: All the claims made on your leaflet weren't at all supported by evidence.

senses.sense: to hold the weight of someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Is this ladder strong enough to support me?
senses.lear_examp: Next, electricity is transported by high voltage cables supported by towers up to a transformer station.

senses.sense: help or encouragement given to someone when they are having problems
senses.dict_examp: Carol gave me a lot of support when I lost my job.
senses.lear_examp: Mother needs our support now and I'll go as soon as I can.

senses.sense: agreement with an idea, group or person
senses.dict_examp: Environmental groups have gained support among young people.
senses.lear_examp: Dear Julian, I wanted to tell you that you have my moral support.

senses.sense: the money someone needs in order to buy food and clothes and pay for somewhere to live
senses.dict_examp: He is dependent on his father for support.
senses.lear_examp: Receiving my pocket money last week, I was thinking what would happen if I lost my father's support.

senses.sense: giving help or encouragement
senses.dict_examp: a very supportive friend
senses.lear_examp: The sports facilities were perfect, and the people working in the sport center were very friendly and supportive.

senses.sense: to control feelings so that they do not show
senses.dict_examp: I could barely suppress my anger.
senses.lear_examp: He tried to suppress his fear.

senses.sense: to prevent information from being known
senses.dict_examp: to suppress evidence/news
senses.lear_examp: I personally, would bring my child up as a person who is able to discuss and who does not suppress any criticism at all.

senses.sense: to stop someone or something by using force
senses.dict_examp: The rebellion was suppressed by government forces.
senses.lear_examp: With the fresh sound of Clarisse's words of freedom and thought, happiness and nature, there arises in Montag the need of making a move, of rebelling against a flat and empty system that suppresses the individuality of men.

senses.sense: to continue to live or exist, especially after almost dying or being destroyed
senses.dict_examp: The baby was born with a heart problem and only survived for a few hours.
senses.lear_examp: They struggle to survive.

senses.sense: in a position around something
senses.dict_examp: A lot of the children in this school come in from the surrounding                         communities.
senses.lear_examp: If all of you would help by using these facilities, our village could be very attractive  to people from surrounding villages, which could be very good for the economy of our village.

senses.sense: to increase very quickly
senses.dict_examp: Prices surged on the stock exchange.
senses.lear_examp: Followed by a dip briefly afterwards, the value surged to close to 100 million tons in 2002.

senses.sense: a large increase in something
senses.dict_examp: a surge in food prices
senses.lear_examp: Also in technology, we have noticed a surge of the newest trends in even the smallest countries.

senses.sense: to cause or allow something to continue for a period of time
senses.dict_examp: The team may not be able to sustain this level of performance.
senses.lear_examp: And they have to work hard to reach and sustain this high level.

senses.sense: to support someone or something so that they can live or exist
senses.dict_examp: The money he received was hardly enough to sustain a wife and five children.
senses.lear_examp: The one concern I have is the ability of such a job to financially sustain an entire family.

senses.sense: an event that you did not expect to happen
senses.dict_examp: Don't tell Anne we're having a party for her - I want it to be a surprise.
senses.lear_examp: Last month I had a beautiful surprise for my birthday because my sister bought me a new bike.

senses.sense: the feeling that you get when something happens that you did not expect
senses.dict_examp: He looked at her in/with surprise.
senses.lear_examp: He stared at me in surprise and didn't say anything.

senses.sense: to make someone feel surprise
senses.dict_examp: The news surprised everyone.
senses.lear_examp: Then I saw a blue light that surprised me, I was scared. A strange creature was standing in front of me. It was fat and ugly and then it tried to grab me...

senses.sense: not expected and making someone feel surprised
senses.dict_examp: He gave a very surprising answer.
senses.lear_examp: That was a little bit surprising because I'm pretty small and it's hard for me to find clothes that really fit me!

senses.sense: the place where someone or something is and the things that are in it
senses.dict_examp: beautiful/comfortable surroundings
senses.lear_examp: The larger animals who aren't threatened should live in their natural surroundings.

senses.sense: the name that you and other members of your family all have
senses.dict_examp: Her first name is Sarah but I don't know her surname.
senses.lear_examp: Her name is Teresa and her surname is unknown to us.

senses.sense: the sport of riding on a wave on a special board
senses.dict_examp: Let's go surfing this afternoon.
senses.lear_examp: My hobbies are surfing and football.

senses.sense: able to continue over a period of time
senses.dict_examp: sustainable development/growth
senses.lear_examp: This is as you might know the aim of the concept of sustainable development.

senses.sense: causing little or no damage to the environment and therefore able to continue for a long time
senses.dict_examp: sustainable energy
senses.lear_examp: Being an engineer in the field of renewable and sustainable energy which includes solar energy, hydropower and wind energy, I can say I am quite knowledgeable about the specific problem of environmental issues and about how to mitigate the serious impacts.

senses.sense: the feeling of excitement or nervousness that you have when you are waiting for something to happen
senses.dict_examp: There is a gradual build-up of suspense throughout the movie.
senses.lear_examp: Exciting, fun and full of suspense, I'm sure I'm going to enjoy it, and remember it as a very good time.

senses.sense: someone who continues to live after almost dying because of an accident, illness, etc.
senses.dict_examp: Rescuers have given up hope of finding any more survivors.
senses.lear_examp: We were the only survivors.

senses.sense: to not allow someone to go to work or school for a period of time because they have done something wrong
senses.dict_examp: Two students were suspended for damaging school property.
senses.lear_examp: The director decided to suspend the girl because she had been rude.

senses.sense: to stop something happening or existing for a short time
senses.dict_examp: The ferry service has been suspended for the day because of bad weather.
senses.lear_examp: At first the electrical and gas power were cut off and the transport was suspended but now everything is working.

senses.sense: when someone or something continues to live or exist, especially after a difficult or dangerous situation
senses.dict_examp: The doctors told my wife I had a 50/50 chance of survival.
senses.lear_examp: For many animals zoos are their only hope for survival: for example, the Chinese panda or white eagle.

senses.sense: used to show that you believe something is very likely
senses.dict_examp: Surely they'd have called us by now to say they're not coming.
senses.lear_examp: Surely the trip with your parents will be very nice.

senses.sense: used to express surprise that something has happened or is going to happen
senses.dict_examp: Surely you don't expect me to believe that?
senses.lear_examp: Surely it doesn't mean that they have learned the exciting news?

senses.sense: to stop fighting and admit that you have been beaten
senses.dict_examp: Rebel troops are refusing to surrender.
senses.lear_examp: Without the fire Ralph and Piggy have to surrender and as Piggy now has lost his vision he becomes weak and vulnerable and he must die - "The weak must go to the wall".

senses.sense: making you feel that something illegal is happening or that something is wrong
senses.dict_examp: suspicious  behavior/circumstances
senses.lear_examp: Talking to Calloway made Martins very suspicious, because he had always thought of him as a nice and decent person.

senses.sense: not trusting someone or something
senses.dict_examp: Many of them remain  suspicious of journalists.
senses.lear_examp: Paul was suspicious and asked her if she was all right. Jane replied with a yes, but she looked nervous.

senses.sense: a doctor who is specially trained to perform medical operations
senses.dict_examp: He is a leading surgeon at a London hospital.
senses.lear_examp: I have been a surgeon for almost 20 years now, and I have worked in many different situations.

senses.sense: to look at information on the Internet by moving from one page to another using electronic links
senses.dict_examp: Are you working or just surfing?
senses.lear_examp: I  like it very much because it is cool and I can do a lot of things with it, such as playing games and surfing the Internet.

senses.sense: to ride on a wave as it comes toward land, while standing or lying on a special board
senses.dict_examp: I spent the summer learning how to surf.
senses.lear_examp: I really enjoyed learning how to surf, it was terrific.

senses.sense: feeling surprise because something has happened that you did not expect
senses.dict_examp: You’d be surprised how quickly the time passes.
senses.lear_examp: Hi Jo, I'm surprised you can't find the information about the art class.

senses.sense: to move your throat in order to make food or drink go down
senses.dict_examp: My throat is so sore that it really hurts when I swallow.
senses.lear_examp: I swallowed my eggs and bread and checked my bag for the fourth and last time.

senses.sense: to accept something unpleasant
senses.dict_examp: They found the final decision hard to swallow.
senses.lear_examp: Occasionally he would beat her, but she just swallowed it with a sense of helplessness.

senses.sense: to not show your feelings and to not allow them to affect the way that you behave
senses.dict_examp: I swallowed my pride and asked them for help.
senses.lear_examp: She has had to put up with all the psychological harm that her husband has put her through and at the same time, she has had to keep on struggling for her children, never giving in; holding back her tears, swallowing her pride just for the benefit of her daughters.

senses.sense: to think that something is probably true, or is likely to happen
senses.dict_examp: They suspected (that) he was lying.
senses.lear_examp: I started to suspect that something wrong was happening there and I was about to leave that place when I heard some of my friends calling for me.

senses.sense: to think that someone may have committed a crime or done something bad
senses.dict_examp: The police suspect him of stealing the car.
senses.lear_examp: But other people were suspected of having killed them.

senses.sense: to not trust someone or something
senses.dict_examp: She suspected his motives for offering to help.

senses.sense: someone who may have committed a crime
senses.dict_examp: He's the prime suspect  in the case.
senses.lear_examp: He had never thought that Doctor Quimper might have been a suspect, as well.

senses.sense: to be or go everywhere around something or someone
senses.dict_examp: Snow-capped mountains surround the city.
senses.lear_examp: The place I've enjoyed most is a small lake surrounded by very tall trees and a lot of bushes.

senses.sense: If a feeling or situation surrounds an event, it is closely connected with it.
senses.dict_examp: Mystery still surrounds the exact circumstances of his death.
senses.lear_examp: However, there was at this point nothing pleasant about the atmosphere surrounding the house.

senses.sense: in a way that shows that you do not trust someone or something
senses.dict_examp: He looked at her suspiciously.
senses.lear_examp: The old man, who was going upstairs, stopped and looked at us very suspiciously.

senses.sense: when a doctor cuts your body open and repairs or removes something
senses.dict_examp: heart surgery
senses.lear_examp: My mother had to go through gall-stone surgery in Finland, where she was spending her holiday.

senses.sense: an examination of opinions, behavior, etc., made by asking people questions
senses.dict_examp: A recent survey found/showed that 58% of people did not know where their heart is.
senses.lear_examp: I have made a little survey on the subject of my report and I have found that most of the pupils of our school consider that the region and the area around the school should be filmed first.

senses.sense: to ask people questions in order to find out about their opinions or behavior
senses.dict_examp: Seventy-five percent of those surveyed were in favor of the proposal.
senses.lear_examp: Of the people surveyed, only 22% of the people responded that they never visit the park.

senses.sense: to look at or examine something carefully
senses.dict_examp: I got out of the car to survey the damage.
senses.lear_examp: This means that we need a small team to survey the area first, and I am very happy to lead this team.

senses.sense: the degree to which something is sustainable
senses.dict_examp: We have to think about the sustainability of these energy sources.
senses.lear_examp: State and Society should be held responsible for ensuring the environment's sustainability and for preventing further damage.

senses.sense: the top or outside part of something
senses.dict_examp: The sun was reflected on the surface of the water.
senses.lear_examp: When we came back to the surface we just looked like real miners.

senses.sense: what someone or something seems to be like when you do not know much about them
senses.dict_examp: On the surface, he seemed very pleasant.
senses.lear_examp: Miss Marple on the other hand is an old, nervous but gentle lady on the surface but inside that head of hers there is a brain as sharp as a knife, cutting through the mysteries she is involved in.

senses.sense: to be or do better than someone or something else
senses.dict_examp: The book's success surpassed everyone's expectations.
senses.lear_examp: I visited "The Acropol" restaurant two weeks ago and to my astonishment it surpassed all my expectations.

senses.sense: unexpectedly or in a way that is unusual
senses.dict_examp: These chairs are surprisingly comfortable.
senses.lear_examp: Surprisingly, I saw my grandmother walking in the rain!

senses.sense: an amount of something that is more than you need
senses.dict_examp: Every year we produce a huge surplus of wheat.
senses.lear_examp: The most developed countries are the ones who didn't have a surplus of food and they had to find a way of producing it.

senses.sense: a belief or idea that something may be true
senses.dict_examp: Some people have suspicions that he may not be able to play at all.
senses.lear_examp: I asked my mother what had happened and she confirmed my suspicions.

senses.sense: a feeling or belief that someone has committed a crime or done something wrong
senses.dict_examp: His strange behavior raised suspicions among his co-workers.
senses.lear_examp: Some of us were told to go there and to kill those who were under suspicion.

senses.sense: with a taste like sugar
senses.dict_examp: The pineapple was sweet and juicy.
senses.lear_examp: I like rice and sweet dishes.

senses.sense: attractive, often because of being small
senses.dict_examp: Look at that kitten - isn't she sweet?
senses.lear_examp: It's a toy bear and it's so sweet.

senses.sense: kind and friendly
senses.dict_examp: It was really sweet of you to help.
senses.lear_examp: Thank you ever so much for the present you've sent me! It was really sweet of you.

senses.sense: when you show that you understand and care about someone's problems
senses.dict_examp: The president has sent a message of sympathy to the relatives of the dead soldiers.
senses.lear_examp: No matter how sensitive or impassive one's attitude towards animals is, after having thought it over thoroughly most of us feel deep sorrow and sympathy for the poor creatures kept in cages.

senses.sense: agreement with or support for someone's ideas or actions
senses.dict_examp: Scott was in sympathy with this view.

senses.sense: happening or moving quickly
senses.dict_examp: a swift response
senses.lear_examp: Individual performances were amazing. Jimmy Page's heavy blues riffs, his swift solos and his talent for composing songs of an incredible richness clearly showed he was still one of the greatest figures of rock 'n' roll.

senses.sense: If one thing is synonymous with another, they are very closely connected with each other in people's minds.
senses.dict_examp: It is a country where wealth is synonymous with corruption.
senses.lear_examp: Working is synonymous with integration in the society.

senses.sense: If one word is synonymous with another, they have the same meaning.
senses.dict_examp: Would you say that 'idle' is completely synonymous with 'lazy'?

senses.sense: someone who is swimming or who can swim
senses.dict_examp: Oliver is a very strong swimmer.
senses.lear_examp: He is the best swimmer in the club, much faster than I could ever be.

senses.sense: to move smoothly backward and forward, or to make something do this
senses.dict_examp: He walked briskly along the path swinging his rolled-up umbrella.
senses.lear_examp: When Mary entered the bar, the room was empty and there was a rope swinging from a beam.

senses.sense: a chair hanging on two ropes that children sit on and swing backward and forward
senses.dict_examp: Jake wanted me to push him on the swing.
senses.lear_examp: Do you remember the swing by the big tree in my garden?

senses.sense: a weapon with a long sharp metal blade and a handle, used especially in the past
senses.dict_examp: He rode toward me, waving his sword in the air.
senses.lear_examp: I took the ancient sword in my hands and felt the power flow through my veins.

senses.sense: something that has both a positive and a negative effect
senses.dict_examp: Being that intelligent is a double-edged sword - he finds it difficult to talk to ordinary people.
senses.lear_examp: As you might see, technological advancements are a double-edged sword.

senses.sense: a large, white bird with a long neck which lives on lakes and rivers
senses.dict_examp: We saw two swans gliding down the river with their signets.
senses.lear_examp: The ugly duckling became a beautiful swan.

senses.sense: a physical feeling or problem which shows that you have a particular illness
senses.dict_examp: He's complaining of all the usual flu symptoms - fever, headache, muscle ache.
senses.lear_examp: We asked her what had happened and she told us she had some weird symptoms so she went for an examination to see what was wrong. She finally discovered that... she was pregnant!

senses.sense: a problem that is caused by and shows a more serious problem
senses.dict_examp: This endless debate is a symptom of our lack of confidence.
senses.lear_examp: The problem with tackling homelessness is that it is just a symptom.

senses.sense: to use language which people think is rude or offensive
senses.dict_examp: He started swearing for no good reason.
senses.lear_examp: When I heard the ringing of the phone I became so furious that as soon as I answered the phone, I started swearing at it.

senses.sense: to make a serious promise
senses.dict_examp: swear allegiance/to tell the truth
senses.lear_examp: That day I swore to myself that I would never trust anybody again.

senses.sense: used to say that you are sure something is true
senses.dict_examp: I could have sworn that she said she lived in Canterbury.
senses.lear_examp: I would have sworn that they were our neighbor's dogs.

senses.sense: larger than usual
senses.dict_examp: a bruised, swollen face
senses.lear_examp: I cried almost all day and wanted to go home as quickly as possible but suddenly, someone took a photograph of me with swollen eyes.

senses.sense: to give something to someone and get something from them in return
senses.dict_examp: Would you mind if Dave swapped places with you for a bit?
senses.lear_examp: People come here to swap opinions and news.

senses.sense: to understand and care about someone's problems
senses.dict_examp: It's a really bad situation - I do sympathize with her.
senses.lear_examp: In our lives, it is crucial that we develop relationships between other individuals, in order to have somebody to sympathize with us in bad times and stand on our side to help us.

senses.sense: to agree with or support someone's ideas or actions
senses.dict_examp: I sympathize with the general aims of the organization.
senses.lear_examp: As a result, they tend to sympathize with more radical groups and parties in order to support a change in the current system.

senses.sense: an area of water that has been made for people to swim in
senses.dict_examp: an indoor/outdoor swimming pool
senses.lear_examp: I like it when we go to the swimming pool.

senses.sense: a sign, shape or object that is used to represent something else
senses.dict_examp: Five interlocking rings is the symbol of the Olympic games.
senses.lear_examp: This was the first time it arrived and it was a point of hope for all the friends of nature and particularly for the World Wildlife Fund, who have chosen the panda as their symbol.

senses.sense: sweet food such as cake or candy
senses.dict_examp: Rosie tries to avoid sweets.
senses.lear_examp: Yes, if you can bring some sweets and some snacks, it would be great!

senses.sense: representing something else
senses.dict_examp: symbolic meanings
senses.lear_examp: The reason why people value certain items so greatly is that these items have a great symbolic value to their owners.

senses.sense: a warm piece of clothing which covers the top of your body and is pulled on over your head or buttons down the front
senses.dict_examp: Put a sweater on if you're cold.
senses.lear_examp: I got lots of presents, for example I got a nice sweater.

senses.sense: quickly
senses.dict_examp: The authorities have moved swiftly to quell the violence.
senses.lear_examp: Time seems to flow more swiftly when we need it most, and those two days went by without us having finished the paper.

senses.sense: showing that you understand and care about someone's problems
senses.dict_examp: He suffers from back trouble too, so he was very sympathetic about my problem.
senses.lear_examp: Nobody wants to talk to him apart from Alice, she feels sympathetic and understands him.

senses.sense: agreeing with or supporting someone's ideas or actions
senses.dict_examp: He was sympathetic to their views.
senses.lear_examp: I hope you'll be sympathetic to our demands and take some action.

senses.sense: a set of connected pieces of equipment that operate together
senses.dict_examp: They've had an alarm system installed at their home.
senses.lear_examp: They had a new sound system which is very loud.

senses.sense: a way or method of doing things
senses.dict_examp: the legal/education system
senses.lear_examp: You will have the possibility to get to know our political system.

senses.sense: parts of the body that work together in order to make something happen
senses.dict_examp: the body's digestive/immune system
senses.lear_examp: Now stem cells are widely used in cosmetic surgery - this extremely expensive treatment is offered to well-off people who want to look younger and strengthen their immune system.

senses.sense: a piece of clothing made of soft cotton which covers the top of your body and is pulled on over your head or zips up the front
senses.dict_examp: a hooded sweatshirt
senses.lear_examp: Well, I'm always wearing tight-fitting, blue jeans, I really love them as they're always in fashion, and if it's cold, a v-neck, long sleeved sweatshirt.

senses.sense: to change from one thing to another
senses.dict_examp: She started studying English at college, but switched to Business Studies in her second year.
senses.lear_examp: For many years I had created my system under MS-DOS (Disk Operating System), but two years ago I switched and since them I've worked with Unix.

senses.sense: to turn off a light, television, etc. by using a switch
senses.dict_examp: Remember to switch the computer off.
senses.lear_examp: They couldn't call me because my phone was switched off.

senses.sense: to turn on a light, television, etc. by using a switch
senses.dict_examp: Could you switch the light on?
senses.lear_examp: We will switch on a light and will sing "Happy Birthday" and the party will begin.

senses.sense: a small object that you push up or down with your finger to turn something electrical on or off
senses.dict_examp: a light switch
senses.lear_examp: Then I turned off the switch until the end of the day.

senses.sense: to clean the floor using a brush
senses.dict_examp: I swept the floor.
senses.lear_examp: I found your watch yesterday, while I was sweeping the floor.

senses.sense: to be pushed or carried along in a forceful way
senses.dict_examp: Many trees were swept away in the flood.
senses.lear_examp: Suddenly, we were swept away by an avalanche.

senses.sense: to move quickly, especially in a way that shows you think you are important
senses.dict_examp: She swept past me in the corridor.
senses.lear_examp: Arriving at the central station, we wee met by a roar of "We are red! We are white! We are Danish dynamite!" and let ourselves be swept along with the stream of people from all over the suburbs heading toward the city hall square of our Capital.

senses.sense: the salty colorless liquid that comes through your skin when you are hot, nervous or ill
senses.dict_examp: The sweat was pouring off me ten minutes into the game.
senses.lear_examp: Pearls of sweat appeared on her forehead.

senses.sense: to produce liquid through your skin because you are hot, nervous or ill
senses.dict_examp: The room was hot and I was starting to sweat.
senses.lear_examp: I began to sweat and my fear changed to panic when we opened a door.

senses.sense: a word or phrase that means the same as another word or phrase
senses.dict_examp: 'Quick' and 'fast' are synonyms.
senses.lear_examp: Dynamic, Go-Getters, Ambitious, Stalwarts - These are just some of the synonyms that the young people of today's generation are known by.

senses.sense: to move through water by moving your body
senses.dict_examp: We spent the day on the beach but it was too cold to swim.
senses.lear_examp: I like this place because I like to swim.

senses.sense: a time when you swim
senses.dict_examp: Do you want to go for swim this afternoon?
senses.lear_examp: I would like to play volleyball on the beach and have a swim in the sea.

senses.sense: a piece of clothing you wear to go swimming
senses.dict_examp: I bought a new swimsuit.
senses.lear_examp: It's hot here, but I have my swimsuit, so, this afternoon I'll go to the beach or to the swimming pool.

senses.sense: a list of the subjects that are included in a course of study
senses.dict_examp: Freud isn't on the syllabus.
senses.lear_examp: Physical Education is now generally considered an important part of a person's progress towards a mature, well-rounded adult human being, a fact that is reflected by the inclusion of Physical Education as an obligatory subject in national school syllabi.

senses.sense: the activity of moving through water by moving your body
senses.dict_examp: Let's go swimming today.
senses.lear_examp: I want to go swimming and cycling.

senses.sense: in a systematic way
senses.dict_examp: We went through all the documents systematically.
senses.lear_examp: Unemployment is a major problem today but it can be dealt with systematically and it is worth investing in a solution to this problem because of the social implications.

senses.sense: done using a fixed and organized plan
senses.dict_examp: the systematic collection and analysis of information
senses.lear_examp: On account of systematic and thorough rationalization in almost every sector of Western economics, workers are not needed as they were in the fifties or sixties.
